May 12, 1923.

J. D. McLean, Esq.,
Asst. Deputy & Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir:

We are today in receipt of a copy of letter which you have forwarded to the different Indian Schools owned by the Government in which you advise they are exempt from Sales Tax on all their purchases for their own use. We supply quite a number of these Indian Schools with goods, and have in the past added Sales Tax on all invoices.

We would be pleased if you would give us a list of all the Schools owned by the Government, and we will in future see that this charge is not made.

Yours truly,

THE HOLIDAY-SHEPPARD LIMITED.

Per [signature]

JLH/IC
Ottawa, May 30th, 1923.

Gentlemen:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 12th instant, requesting to be supplied with a list of schools owned by the Government which are exempt from sales tax on all purchases for their own use.

In reply I beg to state that the following Government owned residential schools in Western Ontario and the Prairie Provinces are exempt from payment of sales tax, viz:

Fort Frances Indian Boarding School, Fort Frances, Ont.,
Kenora Indian Boarding School, Kenora, Ont.

Fort Alexander Indian Boarding School, Fort Alexander, Man.,
Cross Lake Indian Boarding School, Cross Lake, Man.,
Sandy Bay Indian Boarding School, Marius, Man.,
Norway House Indian Boarding School, Norway House, Man.,
Brandon Industrial School, Brandon, Man.,
Portage Indian Boarding School, Portage la Prairie, Man.,
Elkhorn Industrial School, Elkhorn, Man.,
MacKay Indian Boarding School, The Pas, Man.

Qu'Appelle Industrial School, Lebret, Sask.,
Pile Hills Indian Boarding School, Balcarres, Sask.,
Gordon's Indian Boarding School, Punnichy, Sask.,
Lac la Ronge Indian Boarding School, Lac la Ronge, Sask.

Crossfoot Indian Boarding School, Cluny, Alta.,
Blood (R.C.) Indian Boarding School, Standoff, Alta.,
Edmonton Industrial School, Edmonton, Alta.,
Old Sun's Indian Boarding School, Gleichen, Alta.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

The Holiday-Sheppard Limited,
179 Bannatyne Ave. E.,
Winnipeg, Man.
To The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Dear Sir:

Kindly advise us if the following and similar institutions are exempt from Sales Tax -

Kamloops Industrial School, Kamloops, B.C.
St. Mary's Mission, Mission, B.C.
Williams Lake Industrial School, Williams Lake, Cariboo, B.C.

Yours truly,

MACKAY SMITH, BLAIR & CO., LTD.,

LAG/R
Ottawa, June 20, 1923.

Gentlemen:

Replying to your letter of the 13th instant, I have to inform you that the Kamloops Industrial School, which is the property of the Government, is exempt from sales tax on all purchases for the use of the school. The St. Mary's Mission and Cariboo (Williams Lake) Schools, which are the property of the church authorities, are subject to payment of the sales tax on their purchases.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

Messrs. Mackay Smith, Blair & Co., Ltd.,
Vancouver,

FEATURES OF SUPERIORITY IN THE

Silent Sanitary School Desks

It is Sanitary.—The one-piece standard with its perfect shield for the book-box presents no dust pockets or germ-breeding ledges, either inside or outside. Even the feet have been filled in so that a round surface is presented where dust and germ cannot lodge.

Beauty of Design.—The prevailing idea of simplicity is splendidly carried out. The proportions are unusually graceful, and the desks present an appearance in the school room.

Comfort Curves.—The seat and back are so shaped that they insure restfulness, at the same time keeping the pupil's body in a hygienic position.

Strength-Construction.—By scientific calculation and practical test, we have distributed the weight so that the weight is borne by the greatest strain comes. This construction insures the essential feature of any school desk—absolute rigidity.

Foot Rest and Protection Board.—This is thoroughly protected. Each end rests in an iron socket in the leg, and is further secured by screws passing through the iron standard into the floor. The foot rest is placed in a slanting position so that the desk slips off the casters automatically. This also acts as a protection board, preventing one pupil from annoying the pupil in front and soiling his or her clothing.

Book Shelf.—Unusually roomy, so that a quantity of books can be easily accommodated. The sanitary standard prevents the books from becoming cleanliness. No foreign matter can be thrown into the book-box and interfere with the passage up and down the aisle. The book shelf is screwed permanently into place.

Individual Sizes.—Every casting is made from an individual pattern, giving exact and symmetrical proportions to the various sizes.

Space Economy.—Every possible saving of space has been reduced to a minimum, yet sufficient space has been left to prevent the catching or pinching of any part of the body.

Screw Holes.—The screw holes are not cast, but are machine drilled, and counter-sunk.

Sweeping Room.—The arch in the casting gives ample space for thorough sweeping—no excuse for dirt being left under the desk.

Noiseless, Automatic Seat Hinge

FIGURE A

The Automatic Seat Hinge is absolutely noiseless and will not loosen. In operation, the parts automatically tighten themselves.

Figure "A" shows the parts of the "sanitary Noiseless" Hinge.

The ball in the inside of the seat arm casting (1) rests in the socket in the hub of the desk casting (2). A hardened steel roller (3) runs in the hollow (4) of the hub. This roller bears against the eccentric (5) as the seat is lowered or raised. The bolt (6) passes through the seat arm casting and the hub, and is held in place by the nut (7). The nut lock (8) prevents the nut (7) from working loose from the bolt (6).

The seat arm casting operates entirely within the hub, and the bolt is used only to hold the parts in place. The construction of the hardened steel roller permits the gradual increase of friction between the hardened steel roller working against the eccentric, given a gradually increasing resistance until the seat is brought to a full stop. This permits the perfect adjustment of all parts that the hinge is absolutely frictionless and noiseless. The greater strain on the seat is when the seat is lowered, and the roller is naturally located where the eccentrics are located. With this hinge any spreading where the eccentrics are located forces the hinge-strap more securely in place than the operation of the hinges, therefore, simplifies the manufacture of the ingenious parts.

Figure "B" shows the hinge with parts of the seat arm removed so that you can see the position of the hardened steel roller and the eccentrics when the seat is lowered. Like metal, working against like metal, would rapidly wear away. The resilient steel roller, however, permits a slight yielding so that there is no grinding or crushing of the parts. The hinge is absolutely noiseless, and its ingenious construction forces it to tighten itself when in operation.

Silent Sanitary School Desks

How Many Will Your School Room Seat?

The plan and table on this page have been prepared for your convenience in figuring the number of desks you need. Also space may vary being governed by local laws and conditions. The builders have suggested the standard aisle widths. The suggested width of the outer aisle is designated "A" (the inner aisle is "B"). The distance from the top of the desk by "D" and the distance from the back of one desk to the back of the next desk by "E". This table was prepared using these measurements of the Silent Sanitary but will apply to any style of our desks by using the measurements given in connection with the description of the various styles.

In setting the desks in rows, it will be advisable to place the desks close together so that they will be wanted before you screw any of them to the floor. If, then, you find that the rows is too long, you can possibly gain some extra space you need by raising up slightly the space you have intended to reserve for the aisle. To accommodate the normal child the seat ordinarily should project about an inch beyond the desk top. Circumstances, however, might alter this rule.

How to Determine the Number of Rows Across the Room

From the width of your room, subtract one wall aisle space. Then add twice the distance across the top of a desk, plus an inner aisle space. The result will be the number of rows of desks.

When figuring in the outer aisle will measure exactly the same as an inner aisle. You may want to widen this and you can, of course, adjust the aisle space accordingly. The number of rows, generally, will depend a great deal on the size of your room, or may be governed by local laws.

Installation of Desks in School Room

We find that in many instances desks are not properly placed in the school room. One size of desks only should be placed in a row, otherwise the advantage of using a modern desk is destroyed.

HOW TO SET UP SILENT SANITARY SEATS AND DESKS

First—Sort up all sizes of Desk Woods putting all woods of each size together. Remember that there are only three different sizes of woods and six sizes of castings. Nos. 1 and 2 Castings take the largest size of wood; Nos. 3 and 4 Castings take the medium size woods and No. 5 and 6 Castings take the smallest size of woods.

Second—Connect a pair of Desk Standards or Castings with a foot rest of proper size. Put in the bolts but do not tighten up fully.

Third—Put on the back. In putting the "worming" of the casting into the "serpentine groove" of the wood it should be about one half inch from its final position. Then using a leather faced block and hammer tap the back on its top edge till the worm and groove are in a position so that the back cannot be loosened by pulling forward, or in other words, till it is driven "home."

Fourth—Put the book shelf in place. Be sure that the ends of the book shelf fit perfectly in the grooves of the casting intended for it.

Fifth—Put on the top. When the groove in the wood is dropped on to the worming of the casting it should leave the top of the desk about one half inch from the back. When the top is on properly drive it forward with the block and hammer until it fits snugly against the back.

Sixth—Put on the seat in the same manner and then draw the foot rest bolts tight and the desk will hold together perfectly till the screws are put in.

Seventh—Put two ½ in. screws in the bottom of the back. Put two ½ in. screws in the outside edge of the top through the projections in the castings. Put two ½ in. screws in their proper place in the seat. Use two 1 in. screws to fasten the top to the back. Hose for these screws are drilled angle wise in the under side of the top. Use ½ in. screws to fasten desks to the floor.

Regulations Governing Purchases - All Departments

Approved Oct. 2nd, 1923.

(1) The Department shall submit to the Committee requisitions showing quantity, quality, kind, where, how and when required, with specifications, if any, together with proposed list of sources of supply, when the proposed expenditure is $1,000.00 or over.

Requirements shall be consolidated as much as possible in order to prevent repeat orders for small quantities.

The requisition shall be approved by the Honourable the Minister of the Department, either at this stage, or later as outlined in paragraph 5 below.

Submission of requisitions and sources of supply may be arranged with the Committee by telephone after specifications and lists have once been approved. The Department will be informed of any corrections in approved lists, and shall, on its part, advise the Committee of any requests for tender forms which it may receive.

(2) The Committee will scrutinize the requisition, and either fill same with goods surplus in other departments or, after examination of the list, return the file to the Department with instructions.

(3) The Department shall call tenders, returnable to the Committee, fixing a due date which will give reasonable time to the trade to prepare quotations. An envelope addressed to the Government Contracts Supervision Committee, Ottawa, bearing in the lower left hand corner the name of the Department, subject and due date, shall be enclosed with the tender forms. Arrangements will be made between the Committee and the Department to fix one or more days per week (and hour) on which tenders will always fall due.
(4) Responses to invitations to tender received by the Committee shall be safeguarded until the due date, when they shall be opened by a representative of the Committee and of the Department. All replies shall be time and date stamped. They shall also be initialed by both representatives and scheduled in duplicate, each copy being signed by both. One copy of the schedule will be retained by the Committee and the other copy, together with all replies will be laid immediately before the Department by its representative.

(5) Tenders shall be examined by the Department, recommendation prepared, and the complete file submitted to the Committee. The transaction is to be approved at this stage by the Honourable the Minister, unless the original requisition has already been so approved when first submitted to the Committee.

The lowest tender in conformity with specification shall be recommended. If the lowest tender is not considered the most favourable good and sufficient reasons for passing over lower quotations must be stated in the recommendation.

Preference shall be given to Canadian made goods whenever prices and conditions permit. When Canadian products are not available, or cannot be recommended, goods of British origin shall be given preference.

(6) The decision of the Committee shall be communicated to the Department with the least possible delay, on receipt of which action as indicated shall be taken by the Department.

The Department shall anticipate and report its requirements to the Committee so far as possible in order to facilitate transfers of goods surplus in other departments, consolidate similar requirements, and enable the Committee to avoid overlapping, effect economies and ensure uniformity and standardization of purchases as between the several departments of the Government.
Pending the reduction of the $1,000.00 minimum, any special price arrangements made by the Committee and communicated to the Department, and any other rulings in respect to special lines of goods, procedure or policy, shall be exceptions to the foregoing regulations, irrespective of the amount involved (e.g., See Circular Letter from the Committee dated Sept. 19th, 1923, concerning the purchase of Ford Cars).

In filling requisitions involving an expenditure of less than $1,000.00, the Department shall invite sealed tenders from the best available sources of supply. Such tenders shall be safeguarded, and opened on the due date by two representatives of the Department. The lowest tender in conformity with specification shall be accepted, unless good and sufficient reasons for departure from this procedure can be given, of which record shall be kept for reference. Preference shall be given to Canadian and British made goods, as already mentioned; also to firms situated in the locality in which goods are required, provided tenders are equally favourable.

Lists of sources of supply approved by the Committee for purchases over $1,000.00 shall be used for purchases under that amount, whenever practicable. If any doubt exists as to sources of supply, the Committee shall be consulted before tenders are called.

A monthly statement, showing total aggregate purchases, shall be submitted to the Committee, which will review same periodically and issue any instructions deemed advisable to prevent overlapping, effect economies and ensure uniformity, as above mentioned. Such monthly total amount shall be subdivided under the following heads:

1. Provisions & Forage.
2. Fuel.
3. Dry Goods, Clothing, Hats & Caps, Beds & Bedding, Tents & Camp Equipment, Fire Hose.
4. Leather Goods, including Leather Footwear & Harness.
5. Rubber Goods, including Rubber Footwear & Garments, Tires & Tubes.
6. Hardware, including Heating Appliances, etc.
7. Building Material, including Lumber.
8. Drugs, Medical & Scientific Supplies and Instruments.
9. Office Furniture, Typewriters, etc.
10. Stationery and Office Supplies.
11. Farming Machinery, Implements & Spare Parts.
12. Electrical Machinery, Equipment and Supplies, including Electric Lamps.
13. Other Machinery and Mechanical Supplies.
14. Vehicles, including Automobiles, Trucks and Tractors and Spare Parts.
15. Aeroplanes and spare parts.
16. Motor Spirits and Lubricants.
17. Miscellaneous.
For purchases involving amounts less than $100.00, or as may be arranged with the Department, competition shall be secured, either by sealed tenders, by letter, by telephone or verbally, except in case of purchases of a petty cash nature, when no competition is necessary.

The Department shall advise the name and title of the officer who is authorized to deal with the Committee in connection with purchases, and the names of the person or persons authorized to act in connection with the opening of tenders.

Full details of unsatisfactory filling of contracts shall be reported to the Committee.

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

The attached letter from Mr. Commissioner Graham gives rise to certain general questions relative to the laundry and its equipment at Indian residential schools. The activity in the laundry serves a dual purpose - the washing for the institution is done and the older girls receive instruction.

In a modern institution of 100 pupils and staff, a sufficient number of labour-saving machines should be installed to permit the washing and sterilizing of the clothes to be done with enough despatch to eliminate the irksomeness attendant upon too many days' labour per week. I believe that power machines for washing, extracting and drying are desirable in the larger institutions. The washer should be fitted with steam connections, so that the clothes may be sterilized. A small steam boiler also is therefore required. This equipment is used for the regular bi-weekly washing of bed clothing, under clothing, shirts, dresses, aprons, etc.

The officer in charge of the laundry regularly gives the girls instruction in the steps to be taken with an ordinary domestic washing. An assortment of articles to be washed is put through by hand for instructional purposes. Further, the girls will receive other experience as in an institution there are certain articles that can best be done by hand and frequently there is clothing to be boiled and washed at short notice. There is plenty of opportunity for instructing the laundry girls in ironing as this is all done by hand.

For the work that is being undertaken by hand the laundry should be equipped with a receptacle for boiling small quantities of clothes, flat iron, a box stove for heating them, stationary tubs and two or three hand wringers. Large wooden receptacles for soiled clothes and tables for ironing and sorting complete the equipment.

Russell T. Ferrier

Supt. of Indian Education.

How to Install our Clean Air System

Save Time and Inconveniences by following our Instructions

1. Open All Packages and Assort Them.

2. Fresh Air Intake.

   Cut the hole for the Fresh Air Intake through the wall, starting it not less than 3½ ft. from the side wall and 9 inches from the floor level. The following are the net sizes of the openings after frame has been put in.

   Furnace No. C—12 x 12 in.
   " D—12 x 16 in.
   " E—15½ x 17½ in.
   Furnace No. F—15½ x 20½ in.
   " G—15 x 22 in.
   " H—18 x 24 in.

3. Chimney.

   Build the Chimney at the entrance end of the building, inside the class-room, and as near the centre of the partition wall between the class-room and the cloak-room, as possible, the flue of the chimney must begin not less than 8 in. below the floor, build perpendicular if possible, and 4 ft. above the peak of the roof or any other obstructions. The Foul Air Openings in the chimney must start level with the floor.

   Flue for No. C—12 x 16 in.
   " D—12 x 16 in.
   " E—16 x 16 in.
   Flue for No. F—16 x 20 in.
   " G—20 x 24 in.
   " H—24 x 24 in.

   Flue to have three air openings, if possible, at the bottom of the Chimney, beginning level with the top of the floor.

   Bottom of smoke pipe hole in the Chimney, 7½ feet from the floor level.

4. Asbestos Paper.

   Put the Asbestos Sheets where the furnace is to stand.

5. Floor Iron.

   Over the Asbestos Sheet put the Iron Sheet. Keep it 15 inches from the back wall, and extend equally distant on each side of the Furnace and nail it to the floor.

6. Feet.

   Bolt the Feet to the base, put it in place and level it, keeping it at least 30 inches from the wall until the Intake Pipe is put in place, when it will be put to its proper place. Be sure that it stands level.
7. Ashpit.

Set the Ash-pit in place and see that it is not only level, but even in front with the shield base rim; that done, take it off again and put Asbestos cement under the edges so as to make it air tight.

8. Firepot.

Set the Firepots level, solid and in cement.

9. Control Doors.

Straighten the Control Doors if necessary and tighten the Bolts through the base-rim.

10. Bottom Inside Shield.

Put on the Bottom Inside Shield marked "A," fasten with \( \frac{1}{2} \) inch bolts near each end of both control door frames and two in front to hold the ends together.

11. Outside Shield

Put it on the Furnace in its proper place, buckle behind. Put on the two door frames and be sure to shove the bottom one into its proper place, as well as the one above it. Mark the holes on the Shield, then lay the Shield flat on the floor with the outside up, punch the frame holes in the Shield. Set the casing on the bottom end and bolt the frames on, then put the Shield with the frames in its proper place, buckle the lower and upper straps behind.

12. Rings.

Lay the inside centre ring into the outer centre ring on a level floor. See that they are both level and round before putting them on the Shield. Then bolt them as per holes made in the Shield.

13. Intake.

Bolt on the intake flue, setting the bottom inside of the shield and the sides and top outside. Put in a bolt or two, couple the control rods to the intake damper. The dampers must be made to work easily and fastened so as to stay, by putting on two nuts on the coupling rod fasteners.

14. Place Furnace.

The intake being bolted on properly, the damper and control doors working properly, set the Furnace so that the back will be not less than 16 inches from the wall.

15. Cement.

Put Asbestos Cement in the inside and outside of the ash-pit and fire-pot grooves.

16. Fire Dome.

Fill the fire-pot groove with cement. Put on the fire dome in the centre, level it, and see that it does not tilt, and set it so that the fire door frame will be parallel and perpendicular with the Ash-pit door frame.
17. **Baffle.**
   Put in the baffle.

18. **Top Shield.**
   Put the top inside shield, marked "C," on the Furnace and bolt it to the shield, and put the ring on.

19. **Top Outside Shield.**
   Put on the top outside shield the same as the bottom outside shield, and bolt the top ring to the shield.

20. **Doors.**
   Put on the doors, frame, see that it is parallel and perpendicular. Mark your door frame holes, then take it off and handle it the same as you did the lower shield. Put on the top rings and fasten them, as you will find holes in the rings.

21. **Top Screen.**
   Put the screen on top of the Furnace.

22. **Smoke Pipe and Damper.**
   Put the damper into the piece of pipe with the holes in, put on the extension rod, then put up the pipe properly. (See Cut No. 3).

23. **Intake Collar.**
   Put the collar on the intake flue on the side next to the Furnace, and nail it to the wall.

24. **Foul Air Damper.**
   Put the foul air dampers on the bottom of the chimney.

25. **Hood.**
   Fasten the Hood on the outside over the intake opening. (Electro No. 7).

26. **Fire.**
   Close the foul air dampers at bottom of chimney, put on a slow fire. Open doors and windows and burn off all the parafine.

27. **Operating Sheet.**
   Nail operating sheet to the wall securely, and see that instructions are followed.
28. Test.

After you get some heat, open the foul air dampers, light pieces of paper and drop them to the bottom of the chimney openings and see what a draft you will get up the chimney, which is a positive test that the foul air on the floor is being taken up the chimney.

A cheap mattress is unsatisfactory from several standpoints - see your 405-11A of April 1, last - and an expensive article soon becomes unsanitary, especially on certain beds, and is then a total loss.

Ticking, filled with hay or oat straw, has been found satisfactory except in matter of appearance and it is now departmental policy to supply a good grade ticking instead of mattresses. Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 11th instant with reference to the supplying of new mattress casings for the Muscowequan Indian Residential School.

I note that the Department, after much thought, is giving a trial to mattress casings only at Indian schools, and that you are not prepared to authorize the purchase of mattresses at the present time for the Muscowequan Boarding School. I have communicated to the Principal the contents of your letter.

I can only say that I am disappointed at the view the Department is taking of this matter. I am today in receipt of a communication from the Principal of the Duck Lake Indian Boarding School in which he asks me if we have any mattresses that he could buy with his own earnings to replace old mattresses in use at his school, and he assures me that he will never use these straw-filled casings in his institution, and I do not blame him for this stand. Father Poulet will no doubt buy mattresses with his own earnings also instead of using these casings. I have had several conversations with the Sisters at these institutions, and I also know from personal observation that these straw mattresses can never be a success in Indian schools.

I hope that the Department will not buy casings for use in the Onion Lake and new Blood Schools and then in a year's time decide that we have to resort to mattresses. It would only be a waste of money if it were decided to buy mattresses at a later date.

The Secretary,
Dept. of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.
I think you have sufficient evidence before you to enable you to decide whether mattresses or mattress casings should be supplied. I consider that Father Delmas and Father Poulet are well qualified to give opinions on this matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

MR. PAGE,

Relative to future purchases of school desks for Indian schools, I have to say that during the past summer when prices have been asked for from the different dealers they all quoted practically the same. As the desks of the various manufacturers appear to be equal in all respects, I would beg to suggest that, instead of sending out tender forms and asking for quotations when desks are required, that the business be as fairly divided as possible among the different manufacturers and dealers.

Dear Sir:

Recently, Mr. Graham, Indian Agent at Regina, made a requisition to your Department for 40 school desks to be supplied to the Indian Industrial School of Fort Alexander, Manitoba. When we learned that this school had received that quantity of school desks, we requested the manager of our Regina office, to interview Mr. Graham, and to find out why we have not been given an opportunity to submit a price for this order. We also instructed him to find out whether in his requisition, Mr. Graham has recommended any special make of desk, or whether it is the rule to leave the selection of the make of the desks to your Department.

We are informed today, by our Regina office, that in reply to our enquiry, Mr. Graham mentioned that as far as he knew, his requisition never specified any par-
Superintendent of Indian Education,

ticular make of school desks, and that the selection is made, and the order given by your Department.

On request which our manager of our Regina office made, that our name be listed amongst those whom you are from time to time inviting to submit quotations for the requirements of school desks, Mr. Graham replied that this could be done only after permission to do so has been obtained from Ottawa.

We have been in correspondence with your Department since a number of years; that is to say, we took the liberty of drawing your attention to the fact that we sell school furniture and blackboards, and we requested your Department, to be given an opportunity to submit our quotations for your requirements.

Several schools have been built, such as in Brandon, St. Paul des Metas, and others before, and your Department overlooked us consistently and in spite of all promises to the contrary, we have not received any request to submit our prices.

Although we are not manufacturers, we are in a position to submit prices which in many cases, will be found lower than those which your Department may have to pay in buying directly from Eastern factories.

This can be explained through the fact that

there is an understanding amongst Eastern manufacturers as to their sale prices, and furthermore, the freight charges for small quantities shipped by L.C.L. are considerably higher than those for carload shipments. Since we receive our school furniture in complete carload shipments, our cost in Winnipeg is such, that we can underquote Eastern factories for your requirements of smaller quantities than carload lots.

Such being the case, we must express our surprise, that 40 desks have been ordered by your Department for the Indian Industrial School of Fort Alexander, Man., without our being given an opportunity to submit a price.

As a matter of fact, and although we are established in Regina since 10 years, we have not received from Mr. Graham, during that time, a single order for school furniture or blackboard, nor have we ever been invited to quote a price.

Dear Sir:

We acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 7th inst., file No.1-1-12, contents of which we have carefully noted.

In reply, beg to say that as far as Fort Alexander Indian Residential School is concerned, and the order which has been placed recently for 40 desks, for same, this quantity was evidently used to furnish completely a classroom. Consequently, we cannot quite follow your argument that it was necessary to have uniformity in seating equipment. Of course, if this quantity of 40 desks had been ordered to complete the seating accommodation in a number of different classrooms, in which were already school desks of that particular make, we could understand that you were more or less compelled to place an order for the same make, so as to have the uniformity of which you are speaking. However, in accordance with our own information, this quantity of desks was used entirely for one classroom, and it seems to us that our, or any other make, would have been suitable. All we are complaining of is that we have not been given an
opportunity to submit our prices.

We repeat that we receive our desks in complete carloads, and your Department could have saved the difference in freight rate, which amounts to about 40 to 50 cents a desk. Although we are the Western distributors of the Canada Foundries & Forgings, Ltd., of Brockville, Ont., you can buy from us this make of desks at a cheaper price for Western requirements than you can get them from the factory. This fact may be explained by the difference in freight rate as mentioned further above.

We regret, indeed, that there is not one word mentioned in your letter in regard to Mr. Graham, Indian Agent at Regina. We complained of the fact that this gentleman has not given us a single opportunity to submit our prices during the last ten years. Whenever our representative calls, he gets the same answer; that nothing is required.

We notice, furthermore, that you overlooked to answer in regard to blackboard. We sell ordinary pulp blackboard, as well as imitation and real slate, and we know that your Department requires frequently this class of goods.

We thank you for the assurance that our prices will be obtained for the new schools at Brandon and at St. Paul des Métis. We beg to remind you that there is also a new school at Punnichy.

Dear Mr. Scott:

You may possibly recall a short interview you accorded the writer when you were in Winnipeg last November, which resulted in a further interview with our manager at Regina, together with District Commissioner Graham, relative to the furnishing of bedding, etc., for the Indian Schools.

As a result of these interviews our Regina manager submitted specifications to you, covering beds, mattresses, pillows, bedsprings, etc., which were drawn up with a view to making doubtful points clear, and to avoid reference to the products of any one manufacturing company. The writer was informed at that time that this action met with your entire approval and that you were satisfied with the specifications as redrawn.

On reviewing our files we noted no inquiries for beds or bedding have been received from you since that date, but, at first, concluded this was due to the usual seasonal inactivities. We were the other day, however, informed by a department manager of one of our large department stores that recent tenders received by them for bedding to be supplied to your Department were definitely refused products manufactured by the Simmons Company, and the tenders worded in such a manner that the firm tendering would conclude there was no advantage to be gained by quoting merchandise manufactured by any other concern.

We can scarcely credit the accuracy of this statement, knowing the fairness of the Dominion Government officials in general and, furthermore, since having had the privilege of meeting you, do not believe you would personally countenance such unfair action.

May we be favored with an early reply.

Yours very truly,

PARKHILL BEDDING LIMITED,

No one has ever devised a better check on the performance of duty by watchmen than the portable clock system, which requires the watchman to carry a clock on each inspection trip and to make a permanent record, by means of keys located at the important points on his route, on a removable dial which is rotated by the clock mechanism and is inaccessible to the watchman.

If the record on the dial, when removed by the one in charge of the watchman, is found to be complete, it shows that the watchman was present at every key station at the times indicated on the dial. If the record is incomplete it shows, unless the watchman can give a satisfactory explanation, that he failed in his duty. Its evidence is permanent and conclusive, and is available not only to the employer but also to the watchman, in case his faithfulness is questioned.

Watchmen are charged with great responsibility. They should be picked men of good character, intelligent, courageous and physically active. Watchmen who have not these characteristics cannot be made competent by providing them with any kind of a clock. But a competent watchman provided with a dependable watchman's clock gives real protection.

The Employers Must Provide the Competent Watchmen: We Provide the Dependable Clocks

An accurate time keeper, capable of running seventy-two hours without rewinding.

Regarding the purchase of the coal required for use at Indian residential schools in Alberta and the other western provinces, I have to say that, as all Indian residential schools in these provinces are conducted under the auspices of one or other of the religious denominations associated with this Department, the school authorities themselves arrange for the purchase of the fuel required. With reference to fuel for day schools, in the prairie provinces and in British Columbia wood is the chief fuel used. The extinguisher must be kept full at all times and be refilled immediately after use in order to maintain the life of this unit. The Underwriters' Laboratories recommend that all extinguishers should be examined and tested at least once a year.

It is a mistaken idea that Pyrene Fire Extinguishers may be left hanging upon a wall or in an automobile, truck, bus or boat for an indefinite period without an occasional inspection, as it is a piece of mechanism to be used in an emergency and it should be tested periodically to prove its worthiness for the same reason that all other mechanisms are so tested despite their excellence of design. We know of no piece of apparatus, especially one immersed in a chemical, however properly designed, that should not be tested at least once a year, and fire extinguishers as a group may not be considered exempt from this.

TO REMOVE FROM BRACKET FOR TEST: Place thumb of right hand at left point of the handle as the extinguisher faces you and with the index finger on the inside right hand of the handle turn the handle with a slight forward movement. This motion not only disengages the extinguisher with perfect ease from the bracket but also unlocks the handle and gives you the extinguisher ready for operation.

It is not necessary when testing these extinguishers that the liquid be ejected or wasted. Test of the pump may be conveniently made by placing index finger of the left hand over the nozzle, withdraw piston about one-third of its length, then remove finger and continue to withdraw piston to about one-half point to see if back action sufficiently expels liquid. We do not recommend or suggest any method of lubrication of the piston because if the extinguisher is entirely filled, the liquid provides its own lubrication. The test may be continued by reaching the index finger over nozzle, forcing piston down again to within one third of the seat, remove finger to see stream and seat handle, locking same as directed on label. Shake extinguisher after testing to remove small amount of liquid left in discharge tube. If tested as above, the amount of liquid lost should not be more than half an ounce.

WARNING: When wholly or partially discharged, refill immediately with Pyrene Fire Extinguishing Liquid only, which can be obtained from your auto accessory or hardware dealer. Do not use water or other substitutes as liquid other than Pyrene Fire Extinguishing Liquid will injure the mechanism by corroding, freezing, etc., and render use on electrical devices dangerous.

The above warning appears on all the labels of Pyrene Extinguishers and disregard of this will certainly mean damage to the extinguisher and render same ineffective in an emergency. In the manufacture of these extinguishers we take great pains to keep moisture away from the mechanism and liquid and it must be stated here that a few drops of water will produce an acid chemical reaction, causing deterioration in a short time.

THIRD:

FIFTH:
Hold acid bottle cage in left hand and slide acid bottle into the cage with the RED END of bottle up.

SIXTH:
Place cage in extinguisher and screw the ring top on tight—record date on tag attached to extinguisher.

Sir:-

I beg to acknowledge receipt of departmental letter No. 1-1-12, dated the 29th ultimo, and note that the Honourable the Minister has requested information concerning the purchase of storage batteries in Saskatchewan.

Since being placed in charge of this Province I have only upon two occasions been requested to purchase storage batteries, both occasions being during the past summer. Pursuant to instructions contained in department letters Nos. 121-5-5 and 121-1-5, dated July 4th, I invited quotations from the following firms for batteries for the Muscowequan and Gordon's Residential Schools:

Lorne Electric Company, Regina
Magneto Service Station, Regina
Hall & Cameron Electric Co., Winnipeg
Gillis & Warren, Winnipeg
Northern Engineering & Development Co. Ltd., Winnipeg
D. Ackland & Son, Winnipeg
Mumford-Medland Co., Winnipeg

Later, under cover of department letter No. 121-5-5, dated July 26th, I was instructed to obtain a quotation from the electric equipment company Limited, Saskatoon, in connection with the battery for the Muscowequan School. I am enclosing herewith the quotations received concerning both schools.

In each instance Messrs. Gillis and Warren, Winnipeg, were invited to quote and you will note from their letters attached that they referred my invitation to quote to Messrs. Bowman Bros. Limited, Regina, who are the Willard battery distributors for the Province of Saskatchewan. In view of Messrs. Bowman Brothers' name not appearing on the preferred list in this office, I did not feel that I was at liberty to enter into negotiations with them with regard to these plants. You will note from the discrepancy in prices, that Bowman Bros. have quoted on a lighter battery than the other companies. Had I been in a position to consider their quotations I would have directed this to their attention. From information I have obtained from men who should know, the load carried by the batteries at both the Gordon's and Muscowequan schools requires a heavy duty battery. Had Messrs. Gillis and Warren intimated that Bowman Brothers acting as their distributors and the business was going through them, I would have submitted this matter to the department for decision.

When inviting

MEMORANDUM:

The Honourable the Superintendent General,

I have Mr. Pratt's memorandum of the 10th instant, requesting to be informed if it is intended to purchase any school equipment for the schools in Alberta in the near future. I understand this refers more especially to the purchase of desks and classroom equipment.

CHIEF PUBLIC HEALTH ENGINEERING DIVISION
With reference to the attached illustrated folder on pasteurization equipment known as the "Starmatic Dairy" the following comments are offered:

The "Starmatic Dairy" does apparently embody the essential features of a complete dairy, even to the extent of including homogenization, cooling and wash vats for sterilization of dairy utensils. Heat for pasteurization is supplied in the standard machines by immersion electric type heater or if desired by steam coils where such construction is preferable where steam would be the appropriate form of heating. In each case the temperature is thermostatically controlled.

Until an opportunity is afforded of examining a complete dairy unit of Starmatic type it is not possible to arrive at any definite conclusion as to its desirability or its usefulness, for isolated establishments, where pasteurized milk or pasteurized dairy products are not readily available. From the description as outlined in their folder it would appear to be serviceable in many instances.

There may however, be certain features of this compact dairy unit that should receive some consideration before determining its usefulness such as:

(a) It is highly developed mechanical unit which may at times require servicing and replacement of parts.
(b) Being an American product of a type which has some limitation in its demand, replacement parts may not be readily available.
(c) If such equipment is to be used in isolated areas servicing as required may not be readily obtainable.
(d) Where temperatures are thermostatically controlled too much reliance should not be placed upon the accuracy of thermostats to give true temperatures at all times, which is most essential and within a definite range limit 143°-145°F for pasteurization process.
With reference to prices quoted or listed on the back of the folder it would appear that a high price is being asked for relatively low capacity units, or essentially one is paying a high premium for a highly specialized mechanical unit of a compact type.

It is possible for one to secure a small 50 gallon pasteurizer equipped with stirring device, valves, indicator thermometer, milk pump and a small surface cooler through which brine could be pumped for cooling purposes at much lower cost and such equipment would serve essentially the same purpose other than homogenization which in itself may not be of prime importance. While no definite figures are at the moment available, the items mentioned above would be secured for less than $1000.00. This of course would be exclusive of steam heating equipment which would most likely be available. More exact figures could be obtained if so desired.

W.R. Edmonds,
Sr. Sanitary Engineer.

Sir:

I have acknowledged the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ult., regarding the employment of Verna Lane, a recent graduate of McGill University, for two months to perform dental work at the various schools in this province.

In reply, I would say that I have seen Mr. Lane today, and told him that he would be employed for a month, and that if he required a further extension of time, we would apply for a certificate. I think it would be well to apply for the certificate now, as it would take two months to finish the work.

You state that I do not mention whether the salary offered to Mr. Lane, namely $150.00 per month, would include the cost of material required for fillings, and in reply, I would say that the salary does not include the cost of material. The estimate is based on about $50.00 or $75.00 buying the material wholesale here; we would be required to pay his living expenses at the various schools, $1.50 a day. The travelling would not be great as most of the places could be reached in about half a day; probably $60.00 would cover this. I might say that if we get the work done for the above estimate, it will be very cheap.

The question of where the line should be drawn in the removal of tonsils and adenoids is one regarding which you will find there is a very considerable difference of opinion even amongst nose and throat specialists.

Regarding the removal of adenoids, if these are obstructing the breathing, there is no question and no difference of opinion as to the advisability of their removal. Indeed, where adenoids actually exist I think it is conceded that removal is the proper procedure.

The tonsil question, however, is somewhat different. Large infiltrated tonsils with crypts of pus or other material should certainly be removed; and, as a rule, in the case of most large tonsils, the proper procedure is removal. Of course, also some comparatively small tonsils are very vicious foci of infection; but, as in many other specialties, I think I can in all fairness say that the procedure of tonsil removal has been carried in some instances to a very great extreme. The conservative advice of some one of experience should, I think, be obtained in all cases in which there is not the positive evidence of the necessity of removal actually visible in the condition of the tonsil itself.

Should you wish it, the Department would be pleased to give you any further assistance possible in this matter.

Report of Dr. R. H. Murdoch (Dentist)
To The Junior Red Cross Advisory Committee

Gentlemen:

INWOOD, September 2 - 12, 1924.

This was the first Junior Red Cross Dental Clinic put on in Inwood since July of last year.

As the schools were not all open it was hard to get notices to all the children. The only school open was the Inwood school itself and this forced me to use some other room. We picked on an old store that was empty and had it cleaned. At this time of year a fire was not needed so we had very comfortable quarters to put on the clinic.

This cleaning out of old rooms and buildings, etc., all takes time but these villages are so small in most cases that the hotels have not enough rooms to allow me to use one for an operating room.

My visit this time was purely operative. I did not go visiting schools and therefore was able to get much more work done. The rural schools did not send their children in as well as I had hoped. The main reason, I believe, being that they had not received work. Then I find that people take so long to decide to send the children for dental treatment. In the first part of my visit work is comparatively slack, in the latter part, I am always nearly overwhelmed with work.

The condition of the teeth in the mouths of those children who received treatment last year is indeed very good, and with the exception of one little filling they needed practically nothing. However, there seemed to be so many more who on account of the large numbers at my last clinic were unable to receive attention and who of course were on a waiting list this time. Consequently, I was kept busy not only from nine to six but often till 10 p.m. and Sundays as well. Before closing this report, I wish to mention again that this clinic was possibly mentioned in my last year's report on Inwood. During inspection of the Inwood schools a year ago I found one case, a girl of about fifteen years of age with several teeth needing filling and the usual lack of healthy teeth with only small cavities but large enough to cause the tooth to ache. As I thought the nerve would either be dead or just saving and knowing that I had not the time at my disposal to treat such a tooth I advised extraction. Needless to say the parents would not listen. Now had they been in a position to pay for their work I would at once have advised them to take their child to Winnipeg but they could not afford this. Therefore it is often this way—when Daddy has a sore tooth he has it attended to, but when some of the children have one it does not hurt Daddy except in the pocketbook. This was the situation in this case.

The result was that nothing was done. The child got through the winter fairly well with just the odd spell of toothache, but this last July it started to ache severely and her face began to swell. The result was that her father drove her twenty miles to the nearest physician and had it lanced externally on her neck. When I saw her the wound had not been healed for six weeks and was discharging pus all the time.

This is one of the best examples of neglect that I have seen. This girl had to be brought to the General Hospital as a Junior patient and will have a scar she will carry as long as she lives. Just at present I have a letter from her asking how soon she can have some false teeth—at the age of sixteen years!

This shows how much pain is being saved these children who take advantage of Red Cross service. I often wonder if they realize what the Red Cross is doing for them.
HARCISSE, September 14 - 20, 1924.

We arrived in Harcissee Monday night, September 14th, where I found the question of accommodation much more acute than at Inwood. There was only one boarding house—a building about nineteen feet by eighteen feet which they were using as a general store, lodging house and also a residence for a family of six children. Rather congested, you will say, but when in the country and especially in my districts we have to make the best of what we can get.

For an office I got the use of a cottage. As the furniture has to be moved to another one anyway, I naturally did not expect to have to pay very much for it, especially as I had to help clean the place up for the settlement. But note the case, the owner was a Scotchman and wanted his dollar a day rent just the same. This point had the poorest hotel accommodation so far and I was charged higher rates than in the best hotels that I go to. Now I believe in paying my way but not in being overcharged so needless to say I cut this clinic just as short as I could. I worked almost night and day while I was there, but did not stay any longer than I had to.

The districts being served from Harcissee are Willowview where the clinic was held last year, Harcissee, and one other school district. Now do doubt those districts would have liked me to stay longer and I would have done so but for the poor accommodation. However, I think we got most of the work well finished except my landlords' children, and as he was the wealthiest man in the district, I thought he could afford to send his children to Winnipeg.

There was one little girl seven years old from Willowview to whom we did a very good turn three years ago when she had all her baby teeth extracted at the Winnipeg General Hospital. Her permanent teeth were starting to go almost as soon as they were through, but thanks to the Junior Red Cross she had them saved.

Our visit at Harcissee although short was a very busy one and both Mrs. Macleod and myself were working till late every evening. With so many permanent extractions, I think the fee should be raised to 75¢ not only because of the work, but also because of the fact that people will rather have their children's teeth extracted for 25¢ rather than filled at 1.00.

LAD DU BONNET, October 10, 1924.

This was our first Junior Red Cross dental clinic ever put on at Lad du Bonnet. Accommodation was good so there was no complaint in that direction.

First I might say a few words about Lad du Bonnet and the class of settlers around there. Lad du Bonnet is situated on the Winnipeg River and the settlers are scattered mostly up and down the river. Accordingly when they have a winter route roads for wagons are not so much needed. It seemed to me that all who could, used the lake as a means of transportation. They only good road is the one towards Winnipeg. I had intended to inspect a number of the outlying schools but as in most cases you have a mile or two to walk after leaving the boat my time did not permit me to do it. Furthermore during my visit there was a great deal of rain. However, I was able to meet the teachers of the schools and was able to give them some idea of what we are trying to do.

There are so many nationalities and the settlement is so badly scattered that it is a most difficult matter to get the people to join for the Junior Red Cross. If they are afraid unless we are very careful they will only support it in name for just they think they can get out of it. The majority of the people are slow to take up anything.
HARCOURT, September 14 - 20, 1924.

We arrived in Narcisse Monday night, September 14th, where I found the question of accommodation much more acute than at Inwood. There was only one boarding house—a building about fourteen feet by eighteen feet which they were using as a general store, boarding house and also a residence for a family of small children. Rather congested, you will say, but when in the country and especially in my district we have to make the best of what we can get.

For an office I got the use of a cottage. As the furniture had to be moved to another end anyway, I naturally did not expect to have to pay very much for it, especially as I had to help clean the place up for the renter. But note the case, the owner was a Scotshman and wanted his dollar a day rent just the same. This point had the poorest hotel accommodation so far and I was charged higher rates than in the best hotels that I go to. Now I believe in paying my way but not in being overcharged so needless to say I cut this clinic just as short as I could. I worked almost night and day while I was there, but did not stay any longer than I had to.

The districts being served from Narcisse are Willowview where the clinic was held last year, Harcourt, and one other school district. No doubt those districts would have liked me to stay longer and I would have done so but for the poor accommodation. However, I think we got most of the work well finished except my landlord's children, and as he was the wealthiest man in the district, I thought he could afford to send his children to Winnipeg.

There was one little girl seven years old from Willowview to whom we did a very good turn three years ago when she had all her baby teeth extracted at the Winnipeg General Hospital. Her permanent teeth were starting to go almost as soon as they came through, but thanks to the Junior Red Cross she has had them saved.

Our visit at Narcisse although short was a very busy one and both Mrs. Lindroth and myself were working till late every evening. With no new permanent extractions, I think the fee should be raised to 75¢ not only because of the work but also because of the fact that people will rather have their children's teeth extracted for 25¢ rather than filled at $1.00.

LAC DU BONNET, October 27 - October 30, 1924.

This was our first Junior Red Cross dental clinic ever put on at Lac du Bonnet. Accommodation was good so there was no complaint in that direction.

First I might say a few words about Lac du Bonnet and the class of settlers around there. Lac du Bonnet is situated on the Winnipeg River and the settlers are scattered mostly up and down the river. Accordingly when they have a winter route roads for wagons are not so much needed. It seemed to me that all who could, used the lake as a means of transportation. They only good road is the one towards Winnipeg. I had intended to inspect a number of the outlying schools but as in most cases you have a mile or two to walk after leaving the boat my time did not permit me to do it. Furthermore during my visit there was a great deal of rain. However, I was able to meet the teachers of the schools and was able to give them some idea of what we are trying to do.

There are so many nationalities and the settlement is so badly scattered that it is a most difficult matter to get the people to work for the Junior Red Cross. I am afraid unless we are very careful they will only support the clinics for what they think they can get out of it. The majority of the people are slow to think anything
now and few have any education. As a result one is kept busy explaining Red Cross and unless we are very careful they are inclined to think that they can get free medical and dental service when they pay a small fee of twenty-five cents a year membership. I tried my best to get this point thoroughly understood.

As there had never been a dentist into this district before I was very busy, mainly with extractions, as they had simply let their children's teeth go. Only in one case did I see any previous dental work done.

Two thirds of the children could not chew their food because of sore teeth. Others had been suffering from toothache for years.

Again I think some publicity should be given to the names of those getting free work done because we are finding difficulty in collecting even the small Red Cross fee. There are always some families who should pay for this work and although I do not regret attending to their children at our clinics but think they should pay at least a fair fee for the work done.

If it had not been for Mr. Murdoch going directly to some of the homes and asking for payment of their small fees the people would not have paid. One man had to be asked to pay for his children's work which at regular dental rates would have cost thirty-five dollars. At Red Cross rates it was about five dollars. He owns a store, Lunch, Studebaker, Bus, Grinder car etc. How I do not think this is right. There should be some way of making this class of patient pay. Of course there are not many of them, but the ones there are should pay more than Red Cross rates.

The majority of people around Lac du Bonnet can pay the Red Cross fee for their children but all want to get treatment without paying. There seems to be only one solution and that is make them pay in advance, because they are not paying even cost of material.

We gave the Lac du Bonnet people an excellent clinic, working evenings and Sundays for them. Over a hundred children were attended to who surely needed attention and few of the parents could afford city fare or regular food. But there are twice as many children left to be attended to yet. Thanks to Mr. Murdoch we collected 75% of our debts.

HILLIE, October 13 - 21, 1924.

Hillie is a little siding about 140 miles north of Winnipeg. As it is nearly two years ago since I put a clinic on for them I thought they were entitled to another one. As accommodation was questionable I let Mr. Murdoch go on to the end of the line about twenty miles further while I got off with my equipment. The hour was about 8 p.m. and everything was under a pitch. After getting my equipment in one end of the box car siding under lock and key I began to look for some place where I could get a little supper as I had had nothing since an early dinner before the train started. But in this respect I was disappointed. As for sleeping accommodation two travellers had the only bed to be found so there was nothing for it but to take a light a fire in the stove which was situated in the box car siding and keep warm until morning. By that time the 6 a.m. train would be through and I could get the travellers bed. Also as soon as the fellows were up my chances would be good for a little breakfast as I was like a wolf in winter. However after being in the army and in a good cool warm places than St. Mary I thought myself lucky.

By morning I secured the travellers bed until the people got up. Then after a little breakfast I found an old horse and rig for school inspection.
Around Hilbre are four schools, Longridge, Birch Bay, Wooddalo and Hilbre. There are as many children in the Hilbre school as in all the others put together.

From a dental standpoint I have never seen children in a worse condition than were some of the children in these districts. They had hardly ever been without toothache for years.

For holding the clinic I found an old cottage that was vacant about half a mile away from the siding with a stove in it. We set up our equipment and started in on extractions and relief of toothache. The people treated us very well and were well pleased with the service they were getting. All went well for about four days when I got a tooth of my own aching under a bridge, so there was nothing for it but stand it as long as I could and then cut through the bridge enough to get relief. As there was no train into town for two days there I was. The next train I ran into the city and had it out. On my return I was into work until all hours. The children were from all four schools and all the schools paid their fees except Birch Bay. They seem to have the idea that anything the Red Cross does should be free. This seems to be the attitude in the border stations. However, I think they know differently by now. They have a lot of fairly nice farms and I do not think that they should have everything for nothing.

Just to give you another, one evening about 9 p.m., I had a boy come in who walked twenty miles to have a tooth out (yes this in Manitoba). I found the Junior Red Cross had provided dental treatment for some children from this district two years ago by bringing them to Winnipeg for eye examination as well. If it was not for the Red Cross these children would be suffering as only those know who have had a real aching tooth and live in a place where no relief is obtainable.

I did not get them all finished so I promised them a clinic next summer. Again I thank the Red Cross for this opportunity of service.

Respectfully submitted,

(Signed) "R. H. Murdoch"

Dear Sir:

The Junior Red Cross since 1922, has been giving a dental service to the children living in the country between Lake Manitoba and Lake Winnipeg. A fully qualified dentist, Dr. R. H. Murdoch, trained also as a teacher, has since that time inspected the children's teeth in the schools, addressed them on the importance of good teeth and finally treated the defects by means of clinics established at convenient centres. I append one of his reports to show the nature of his work and the value of this dental service.

The outstanding feature of the service has been the obvious improvement in the state of the children's health as well as in that of their teeth. Schools which in 1922 had over 80% of the children with defective teeth and with general health below par, showed in 1924 this percentage reduced to 20, with a corresponding improvement in the health of the pupils. The Doctor's visits have a further effect of stimulating an interest in the practice of good health habits through the formation of Junior Red Cross Branches wherever possible.

It has occurred to our Junior Red Cross Committee that our dentist, Dr. R. H. Murdoch, might be able to render service to some of your department's schools in this interlake area. Just as there are dental defects in the provincial schools, so there may be some waiting for correction in your schools. The desire to reach the Indian Schools has often been expressed by Dr. Murdoch on his return from the Fairford and Hodgson districts where your schools are situated.
D.C.S.-S.

If you will give your permission, our Committee will be very pleased to send Dr. Murdoch into one of your schools to give a demonstration of our dental service. Our usual method is to charge each child a small fee as you will see from the attached pink sheet. In the case of your school we would suggest that your Department should pay the travelling and material expenses in addition to providing Dr. Murdoch with board, lodging and a room in which to carry on the clinic. One month should be enough to complete the examination and treatment.

Dr. Murdoch has been on our staff for nearly three years and has proved himself a conscientious, careful and industrious official. He is, moreover, a man of good principle and honorable in every respect. He is thirty-two years of age and married. Thus, in offering Dr. Murdoch's services we have every confidence that you will find his work and personality entirely satisfactory.

Awaiting a reply at your earliest convenience, I am,

Yours faithfully,

[Signature]

Mrs. H. M. Speechly,
Superintendent, Junior Red Cross,
Manitoba Division.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE,
REGINA, SASK., February 10, 1925.

Dear Mr. Scott:

I received a telegram today from Reverend Mr. Bley of Elkhorn Residential School, in which he informs me that George Manningway, a pupil of his school, died this morning.

In a conversation with Mr. Bley over the phone, he told me that three of this family were at the school, and they were all tubercular cases. He claims they were sent to him through the recommendation of Inspector Bunn.

We will have to do something to stop this indiscriminate admission of children without first passing a medical examination. Speaking to Mr. Bley, I told him that this would be done in the future. I think we should instruct all principals and Indian Agents, again, that no children are to be admitted to a school without first having passed a medical test. HINTS ON THE TEACHING OF HYGIENE.

The following is intended merely as an outline of the study beginning from Standard II; and the teacher is advised to make constant reference to the text-book provided by the Department.

1. Practice deep breathing exercises daily. In connection with these exercises be sure that the children breathe through the nose, and endeavour in every way to have them cultivate the habit.

2. Let chest expansion and other physical exercises be practised regularly to the same end as the teaching of hygiene.

3. Study the respiratory system; the functions and care of the nose, throat and lungs.

4. Pure air; what it is, its relation to health, and how it becomes contaminated.

5. The ventilation of dwellings, its importance and the means by which it is secured. Special need for fresh air in bed rooms.

6. Disease germs and how diseases are spread.

7. The effect of sunlight on germs.

8. The fly and mosquito, how they grow and multiply; how they carry disease.

9. Cleanliness in houses and surroundings to prevent the multiplying of flies.

10. Communicable diseases (contagious and infectious.) How to prevent their spreading, the object of quarantine; how it should be observed.

11. Special study of tuberculosis, the spread of the disease and methods of combating it.

12. Diseases of the eye; danger of communication by towels and handkerchiefs.

13. Each pupil be provided with a separate handkerchief and slate cloth.

14. Study the digestive system; the mouth, stomach and intestines and the functions of each.

15. Care of the teeth; causes of decay, how to prevent decay, ill effects upon the teeth of the use of too much sugar.

16. Uses of the teeth; emphasise the importance of thorough chewing of food.

17. Importance of wholesome and well cooked foods; regularity of meals.

18. Importance of pure water and the free use of it except at meal-time.

19. Effects of coffee, alcohol and tobacco on digestion.

20. Study the circulatory system; its organs and their functions and their relation to the health of the body.

21. Study the nerves and the muscles; the importance of exercise and rest; the effects of stimulants and narcotics on the nerves and muscles.

22. Study the skin, its functions, glands and so forth; the importance of regular baths and cleanliness.

23. Care of head; importance of cleanliness. The practice of wearing handkerchiefs on the head in the school-room and indoors generally should be firmly discountenanced.

24. Importance of clean and comfortable clothing.

25. Importance of keeping the feet dry; ill effects of wet feet, colds, croup, sore throat, rheumatism, etc.

Memorandum:

Schools

The question has arisen as to whether the Provincial Regulations directed those in control of schools, colleges, convents, universities or other houses of education to refuse admittance to the institution to any pupil who cannot furnish a certificate from a medical officer practicing within the province of anti-smallpox vaccination, apply to the educational institutions on Indian Reserves. Paragraph 24 of Section 91 of the British North America Act provides that the legislative authority of the Parliament of Canada extends to "Indians and lands reserved for the Indians." Paragraph "A" of Section 98 of the Indian Act provides that the Chiefs of a band in Council may make regulations for the care of the public health subject to confirmation by the Governor in Council, and Paragraph "B" of Section 92 of the Indian Act provides that the Superintendent General may make regulations for the prevention or mitigation of disease, etc. Provision has therefore been made by Dominion legislation for coping with diseases among Indians on their reserves, and when regulations are made in pursuance of this legislation I do not think the provincial law could be enforced on Indian reserves.

Departmental Solicitor.

My idea was that a child should be taken into residence at all until the Department had examined the certificate of health. This could be done quite easily. The Inspectors and Agents are aware that it is the desire of the Department that children shall be physically sound before being admitted to the schools, but this does not stop the Principals of the schools from going to the reserves, recruiting children and bringing them back long distances to the schools without a medical examination.

I should be glad if the Department would take some action to see that no pupil shall enter our schools without a proper examination, the result of which an examination to be approved by the Department or this office before admission is granted. Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on conditions as I find them among the Indians whom I visited in Nova Scotia.

RECOMMENDATIONS.

That the children be provided with one hot meal in school each day. Such meal should consist of hot soup or broth with biscuit, milk, cheese, sugar and cocoa. The actual preparation of this in the school and similar meals would serve a very useful educational lesson.

That for purposes of education in health matters practically all activity be concentrated on the school children and that which can be done with the individual mother as the occasions arise.

Sir:

I beg to submit the following report on conditions as I find them among the Indians whom I visited in Nova Scotia.

SCHOOL CHILDREN.

A large number of the school children appear to be undernourished. It is not unusual to have a school teacher report that it is a common thing for the children to show signs of faintness or weakness in school. When I have taken up this question with the parents the usual answer is for the mother to say that they have not the means to buy such food as milk, butter or eggs for their children.

Practically all the children have decayed teeth, many having enlarged glands; a considerable number suffer from adenoids and enlarged tonsils as well as defective eyesight. A great deal could be done for these children by providing them with a hot lunch of good nourishing food in school. I can conceive of nothing that they would appreciate more or would do the more good.

I have endeavored on all visits to give them, at least, one lesson on health and am getting the teachers enthused along the same line. I feel that the only hope of education in health matters lies among the school children. Very few mothers take kindly to the idea of instruction and so far there has been no indication that they would attend classes organized for such purposes although here and there one does meet with a mother who is anxious to improve and some improvement has been effected, although the bulk of the women seem to think it is hopeless to try to improve in any way under present conditions, their general complaint being that they cannot get the things that are really needed.

Some schools have been supplied with a tank or container for drinking water and the common drinking cup is gradually disappearing.

Owing to the fact that these reserves are scattered over practically the whole length of Nova Scotia and there being no living accommodation within easy reach without hiring daily transportation and also the lack of much evidence on the part of the adults that they will profit by much instruction, I feel that more practical results will be obtained eventually by now concentrating on the school children. Actual demonstration in the schools will be much more advantageous and production of more results than similar attempts in the homes. In this connection it is suggested that arrangements be made whereby some funds would be placed at the disposal of the school teachers to carry on in this fashion with my assistance and supervision.

Orphan Children.

It is seen that it is the practice of selecting or appointing a guardian or foster parents for orphan children and then allowing such guardian or foster parents a small sum of money for the maintenance of each child. The result of this practice is that the whole family attempt to live off of that allowance and do nothing further to provide for themselves, the result being that the poor orphan profits but little from the Department's money. This can be overcome by maintaining such
orphans in the local municipal homes where they would be fairly well looked after and sent to school.

Catherine MacDonald.

Dear Sir,

As Provincial Superintendent of Education amongst Indians, I have been writing the teachers in order to find out what advancement is being made along educational lines, and find from the replies that in many instances pitiful conditions prevail.

There seems to be among the older pupils in the various schools a growing desire for education, and in most instances the teachers (so far as heard from) notice much interest in the advancement of their Indian pupils, but many of them report bright pupils having to stay out of school for lack of medical treatment, sometimes defective eyesight, sometimes diseased tonsils, and in a few cases the need of an operation for appendicitis, and...
"Nothing is too hard for the Lord"

Ontario Woman's Christian Temperance Union

and very often tuberculosis trouble.

I am therefore taking the liberty of calling your attention to these conditions, and would be glad to know if where parents are not able to secure medical aid, the Department would supply the means if cases were reported to them through teachers and clarified by the agency?

Re: Tuberculosis cases, the children dismissed from schools because of this trouble have no future. Such dismissal does not stop the spread of the disease, as they mingle just the same while able to be about with the inhabitants of their locality.

Would it not be possible to establish an industrial home for such pupils, where they could be given a chance? Many of them with care and proper nourishment outgrow the disease, and all could receive some instruction part of the day and take up some carpentry or...
Craft work as their inclination might lead them, as well as gardening and light farm work, and thus be at least partly self-supporting, and cease to be a menace to their home reserves.

The Public Health nurses,

I notice by your Department report that you have established a staff of nurses in Saskatchewan with headquarters at Regina.

Could this not be done also for Ontario? New Ontario seems especially in need of such help. In gathering my report it occurred to me that every town would be a centre from which very effective work could be done. Besides being a help in times of epidemic or reserve, the example and personal touch with...
Indian girls and mothers would be of untold value to them. Mothers among Indians are well aware that they need an example to bring up to and especially when they are old enough to leave school.

We are pleased to find that there are now several Indian girls in course of hospital training and we plan to follow up the gold medal we presented Miss Sampson, our first graduate, by presenting one to the Indian girl taking the highest number of marks each year at graduation.

Thanking you for past courtesies in reference to Indians and knowing you will give these subjects your attention and consideration.

I remain yours Truly,
