Dear Dr. Scott:

Whilst on my tours of inspection this year, I have been taking up with the medical men, the question of a more thorough and adequate check upon the children in the various schools.

Under the present regulations, the children are only medically examined upon entering the school, and unless there is an epidemic threatened, or any of them are sick, the doctor does not, except in a very general way, thoroughly examine these children again.

It is the opinion of the medical men, in which I heartily concur, that the children should be thoroughly examined at least once a year, preferably immediately after the summer holidays. This is only feasible now what is already done by the Health Inspectors at the various Provincial schools, and as the doctors point out, it gives them a chance of getting in touch with any children who may be disposed towards T.B., or any other serious ailments. It would also, considerably help Agents and myself in explaining to the various Indians, in answer to their complaints that the children are not properly fed and looked after.

I should suggest a form something after the style of the form now in use by the Medical men in examining white schools. This form would be of great assistance to the said medical men, in seeing check on the children's health, and would also largely aid the Principals who have to look after the children, and would give most important information to the Agents and myself as to the healthful progress of the children at the schools. Finally, too, it would assist everybody in keeping check upon the prevalence of T.B. trouble amongst the Indian children. You can readily understand that very often when the children are first examined, the doctor can find no trace of any serious disease, and if he does not examine them thoroughly at least once a year, he has no opportunity very often until too late, that the child has developed disease.

Yours, truly,

(Geo. S. Pragnell)
Inspector of Indian Agencies.

Memorandum:

The Secretary.

In addition to the medical work for the Indian in his home, there is an effort to safeguard the health of the youth of our wards who are attending school. 8242 Indian children are enrolled in the 254 day schools in operation. The regular doctors, traveling nurses and field matrons have special opportunity to examine school children and remedial measures can be supervised by the teachers. The Appropriation for Indian Education provides approximately $12,000 annually for the purpose of a hot lunch at half classes of school. Nourishing soups, milk, cocoa and biscuits are the foods supplied most commonly. Hygiene and the proper preparation of food is stressed by the instructors in day schools.

More comprehensive is the effort on behalf of the 6327 Indian children enrolled in the 74 residential schools in Canada. In all our modern buildings, there are special quarters for the care and isolation of the sick, and, at a large number of Indian residential schools, there may be found sleeping verandahs for the children of tuberculosis tendency. MILK VALUABLE TO GROWING BOY

Important Investigation Carried Out In England

INCREASE WEIGHT, HEIGHT

Cow's Product Is a Most Complete Food

By London Pure Milk Company.

The addition of one pint of milk a day to the diet of boys whose appetite of growing boys converted an average gain of weight of 3.5 pounds per year instead of 2.6 pounds and produced an average annual increase in height of 1.4 inches instead of 1 inch.

This betterment in nutrition, by natural processes, was not due to the relatively small increase in the fuel value of the dietary, nor to the extra food energy supplied, but to the specific qualities of milk as a food.

EXPERIMENTS.

The experiments were undertaken under the auspices of the Medical Research Council of Great Britain as a part of an extensive series of studies of the influence of diet upon the growth of the child. The experiments included the observation of 599 to 600 boys living in ordinary London homes.

An analysis was first made of the amount of food eaten by these boys who were receiving under the standard diet and the average rate of growth. The diets were then modified by the addition of milk and butter in specified amounts. However, the other foods remained standard and did not vary. During four years records were kept of the food actually consumed at the table by weighing each sample amount of food after each of the three meals and deducting the waste.

It was found that these boys were taking from 1,875 to 2,134 calories per day—a range of 259,000 calories which 12 per cent were protein, 38 per cent fat, and 48 per cent carbohydrate.

VALUE OF COW'S MILK.

The diets were modified for groups of boys to determine whether the group by the addition of milk to the basic diet of casein, sugar, or butter, or vegetables, margarine, or cheese, and watercress.

It was found that almost invariably there was no growth during summer, and usually more gain in weight at that season.

The groups whose cow's milk was given as an addition to the diet gained far more in both weight and height than those without the milk.

This may be taken as another striking demonstration of the value of milk as a complete food and of the necessity that it form the basic substance in the diet of all growing children.

Memorandum:

Dr. [signature]

With further reference to dental services at Indian residential schools in British Columbia, I wish to report that in the past we have made arrangements for clinics on the following terms:

The fee for amalgam fillings was $1.00. No more expensive material was to be used and only permanent teeth, filled. 25 cents was allowed for each extraction. No cleaning or other dental work was to be undertaken and the dentist was to pay all his expenses. It has been clearly pointed out in the case of each school that the dentist shall do only the absolutely necessary work.

[signature]
Supt. of Indian Education.
Ottawa, April 4, 1927.

Sir:

I have your 809-11B of the 26th ultimo, with reference to dental services at the Elkhorn Indian Residential School. You may offer the work to Dr. Day, on the following conditions: amalgam fillings for permanent teeth only - $1.50, and extractions - 35¢. No cleaning or other dental work should be undertaken, unless there is special authority. No fee can be allowed for dental inspection and only the most necessary work is to be done. The dentist, of course, will have to pay all his expenses. This is in harmony with our general practice when a dentist is asked to put in order the teeth of pupils at Indian residential schools.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,

Dear Sir:

Mr. A. D. N. Daunt of the Department of Indian Affairs, New Westminster, B.C., is much interested in having our volume, "Home Physician and Guide to Health," placed in every Indian school. When our agent in that section called on Mr. Daunt, he immediately became interested in the work and felt that it would be of great value in the schools.

The book, "Home Physician and Guide to Health," is having a wide circulation in all Canada and has become so popular that it has been translated into several foreign languages. It has been prepared by a large group of physicians who have specialized in their line. We believe it is the only book of its kind that is being printed and circulated in Canada today.

We thought you might be interested in looking over this volume so we are taking the liberty of mailing you a copy for your inspection. COMMISSIONER'S OFFICE.

REGINA, SASK., May 23rd, 1927

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 20th instant 119-1-13 regarding the employment of a young dentist to visit all residential schools in the three provinces.

I may say that I have an offer from Dr. McDougall, a young dentist of this City to do the work at the rate of $300.00 a month, the Department to supply materials and to pay travelling expenses. It seems to me that this would be a good arrangement, but unfortunately it cannot be put into effect until after the schools reopen in the Fall, as by the time we got the necessary authority through now it would be drawing near the time of summer vacation. However, I should be glad to have the Department's views on the matter.

Your obedient servant,

W. M. Graham,
Indian Commissioner.

I herewith submit report for the month of June 1927.

In examining the school children throughout the province I find that the majority of them have very defective teeth. Some also have enlarged tonsils and defective vision.

If the children could have decayed teeth extracted and prophylactic treatment given each year it would insure them better health, later on in life.

Catherine MacDonald.

Memorandum:

Mr. Ferrier,

Dr. A.R.Baker, 407 Hastings St. West,
Vancouver, B.C., may be engaged to do dental
work at the Ceqalesetza Institute, and at the
Squamish School in North Vancouver.

D. S. G. I. A.
October 5, 1927.

Dear Dr. Baker:

With reference to earlier correspondence, I should be grateful if you would arrange to perform the dental services required at the present time by the pupils of the Coqualeetza and Squamish Indian Residential Schools. The fees allowed by this Department are at the rate of 25 cents for each extraction and $1.00 for each amalgam filling. More expensive fillings are not authorized. In the case of temporary teeth only extractions can be allowed. The work should be performed at the school. All materials, equipment and transportation expenses should be supplied by yourself.

If you accept this proposal, please inform me and communicate with the principals of the schools and ascertain when it will be convenient for you to undertake the work. The principals in question and their addresses are as follows: Rev. G. H. Bailey, Principal, Coqualeetza Indian Residential School, Sardis, B.C.; Rev. Sister Mary Amy, Principal, Squamish Indian Residential School, North Vancouver, B.C. When I receive your answering communication, I shall inform the principals and local Indian agents and request them to assist you in every possible way.

When the work has been finished at a school, please prepare, in duplicate, a list giving the name of pupil receiving dental attention, and the number of fillings and extractions performed for each. The list for Coqualeetza School should be certified by the principal, who will forward it to the Department for payment, while the list for the Squamish School should be certified by the principal and handed to the local Indian agent.

Yours very truly,

Duncan C. Scott

Deputy Superintendent General.

Dr. A. R. Baker,
407 Hastings St., W.,
Vancouver, B.C.

YOUR PUPILS' HAIR

(A Stimulating Study to be Added to Your Curriculum)

YES, times have changed and nowhere is this more apparent than in the practical trend of modern education.

Most of us remember school as rather a dull place. Many of the studies forced upon our lagging attention were far removed from the glowing, living world outside the school room.

But the world is moving on. Children no longer hate to go to school. Teachers are co-operating with parents in a marvelous way in training eager youngsters to establish habits which will give them strong, healthy bodies and fine minds.

Lessons on the care of eyes, teeth and skin are educating many a parent along with their children; for much learned at school percolates through to the grown-up at home when presented to the child in a vital, interesting manner.

There is, however, one branch of hygiene which seems to have been side-tracked—the care of the hair. Need of this instruction is obvious when one notices the large number of children who come to school with dead, lusterless hair; who have dandruff and even worse contagions, which they spread to those about them.

All of this may so easily be remedied if children are taught at school the latest, scientific methods of looking after the hair. An ounce of systematic care is worth pounds of cure, for a perfectly clean scalp, like a clean body, does not quickly pick up germ or parasitic infections.

Among the old superstitions which are being relegated to the limbo of old wives' tales is the time-honored idea that frequent shampooing injures the hair. Quite the opposite view is held by modern dermatologists and hair experts, while every up-to-date mother can testify to the vast improvement in the looks of her children since the weekly shampoo was inaugurated in the family.

Instruction on how to care for the hair will be eagerly received by the older girls and boys, who are already alive to the importance of being well-groomed when they enter the business world. They hardly need to have their attention called to the fact that Jill easily secured a good position at a fine salary when she graduated from High School because her teeth, nails and last, but not least, her hair looked as if she took pride in her appearance whereas her class-mate Jack, with untidy hair and general don't-care, untidy look, found great difficulty in landing a job at all.

When it comes to the younger child, it may be necessary to awaken a pride in appearance. Gone are the days when the grown-up feared to make tiny Mary vain by talking too much about her looks. The hall-mark of self-respect is pride in outward appearance and such pride is surely a fundamental in character building.

Even the youngest child will respond to a suggestion if his imagination seizes upon the idea and he sees the reason why.
Hence it may be well to begin the lesson with an explanation of the way in which hair grows. The chart on the opposite page shows the anatomy of a single hair. It has been simplified so that it can easily be copied on the board and each part pointed out.

**Something About the Anatomy of a Hair**

The hair is really a part of the skin, as are also the nails. Each single hair (1) is implanted in a hair sac or follicle (2) which is set obliquely 1/12th to 1/16th of an inch into the skin forming the scalp (3). This follicle is surrounded by an outer sheath (4). The papilla (5) from which the hair draws its nourishment is situated at the base of the follicle. It is fed in its turn by the fat cells (6). The bulb (7) at the base of the follicle fits like a cap round the papilla. Oil Glands (8) supply lubricant which keeps the hair soft and glossy. Other glands supply coloring matter. At one side of each hair are tiny muscles which contract in extreme fright and actually cause the hair to stand on end. In cross section, straight hair is rounded while curly hair is elliptic in form.

Each hair is 240th part of an inch in diameter. Women's hair is usually coarser than men's. Hair grows about ½-inch each month. The average head contains 120,000 hairs.

When a hair is pulled out forcibly, some of the pulpy substance adheres to it, but this is not the root, for the hair germ or root remains behind and will eventually grow another hair.
How to Care for the Hair

ADVISE children to brush and comb their hair night and morning, using a moderately stiff brush and a comb with smooth, coarse teeth. A cheap, roughly finished comb will catch strands of hair and break it, or scratch the skin covering the scalp.

This systematic brushing and combing the hair:
1. Keeps the hair in order and gives it a well-groomed appearance.
2. Removes the dust and germs which may have settled on the hair during the day.
3. Stimulates the blood circulation, which urges the glands to do their work in providing the proper supply of oil.

When and How to Shampoo the Hair

It is just as important to wash the hair once a week as to take a daily bath, especially when living in a dirty, dusty city. A special day for shampooing should be ear-marked in every family.

Keeping the scalp perfectly clean does not in any way destroy the natural flow of oil; on the contrary it promotes its functioning freely.

Warm, soft water must always be used when shampooing the hair. In localities where the water is hard, rain water should be saved or distilled water secured for this purpose.

The choice of the shampoo is most important of all. A good shampoo must contain:
1. Cocoanut oil to give lustre.
2. Pine tar to stimulate healthy growth.
3. No alcohol to make the hair brittle, as do most liquid shampoos.
4. No excessive free alkali to bleach and injure the hair, as do most ordinary soaps not especially made for shampooing.

Manner of Procedure
1. Wet the hair thoroughly with warm water.
2. Apply the shampoo and rub to a thick lather over the entire head to the ends of the hair. Keep rubbing until the lather has become stiff.
3. Rinse thoroughly with warm water, using a spray if possible or pour water over the hair with a pitcher.
4. Repeat the lathering operation.
5. Finish with a cooler rinse to close the pores.

After the shampoo, school children should be safeguarded from any infection by having a special fine comb run through the hair while still wet.

Drying the Hair
Gently mop the hair with a warm, thick bath towel. The drying process may be hastened by fanning or using gentle heat. Intense heat should never be used.
If the proper type of shampoo has been used, the hair will dry out soft and glossy. If, however, the hair is unnaturally dry a few drops of almond oil or warm olive oil may be rubbed into the scalp after the shampoo. In any case, this is an ideal time to give the scalp a good massage, which will stimulate the glands and promote a luxuriant growth of hair.

How to Massage the Scalp

The tissues of the scalp should be fairly loose on the bony structure—the skull. Unhealthy hair is often caused by a tight scalp, which can be easily loosened by systematic massage.

Place the fingers on the scalp and move them in a circular motion. Use a firm but not heavy pressure. Work back gradually from the top or sides of the head to the neck until the whole scalp has been massaged. After a few massages you will notice that the tight scalp has become more flexible.

Fighting Hairute Ills on Their Own Ground

THE weekly shampoo is not only the best preventive but the only remedy for germ diseases of the hair and other ills. It must be borne in mind, though, that falling hair may be caused by a poorly nourished system or diseased physical condition. Milk and eggs, plenty of fresh vegetables and water, long hours spent out in the sunshine and proper exercise will work wonders.

Oily Hair This may be the result of an over-rich diet such as too much fried foods, pastries, candy, etc. That "tired feeling" may also be one of the danger signals sent along with oily hair to call attention to a poor physical condition. As a local remedy frequent shampooing several times a week will help the appearance of the hair for the time being, but will not do away with the cause of the trouble.

Dandruff This is an infectious disease, which one person can give to another. The very best preventive known is perfect cleanliness—the weekly shampoo. The next—great care not to use other people's brushes, combs or hats. The first symptoms are tiny, white, scaly bits of skin on the coat or dress collar. If these are discovered early the trouble can usually be cured by washing the hair with a suitable antiseptic shampoo three times a week and using a very fine comb while the hair is still wet. Obstinate cases need the care of a hair specialist.

Falling Hair After a severe illness, the hair frequently loosens and falls out, owing to the lack of nourishment. A general run-down physical condition will also cause the hair to fall. Toning up the system, massage and frequent shampooing with special hair soap will do much to correct this trouble and cause the new hair to grow in rapidly. Many people who have lost practically all of their hair through illness, have been able to grow a heavy, luxuriant crop when they have persistently followed out these instructions.

Pediculosis (Head Lice) This is a most unpleasant, but all too common, trouble when children are massed together in large groups as in school or when they travel on trolleys and other public conveyances. To avoid picking up
one of these parasites, children should be warned not to put their heads together or pile their hats when playing out of doors. Of course, no child should be allowed to use other people's combs and brushes. Children should understand that while it is no disgrace to have caught one of these creatures, it is a crime to allow it to remain in the head even for a few hours. The infection usually shows itself by irritation of the scalp. With such a symptom, a child should be sent home immediately with a printed copy of instructions for treatment. These must be followed out before he is allowed to return. The publishers of this booklet will be glad to furnish leaflets used for this purpose by hundreds of schools throughout the United States (copy enclosed).

**Interest Exciters for the Small Pupil**

Playing on the competitive instinct and stimulating pride by public approbation can both be used to advantage in this connection.

Children, like sheep, have a great deal of the herd instinct and naturally follow one another. When Jack finds that Jill has her hair washed every week and gets much commendation for her improved appearance, he naturally wishes to enter the game, too.

A chart drawn like the one on page 12 and hung in a conspicuous place in the school-room will be a constant reminder and stimulant to hair cleanliness. When a child has been marked for having his hair shampooed for four successive weeks, a gold star opposite his name will set him apart among the upright and make him more enthusiastic to keep up the good work; a certain number of gold stars might have a reward. After all, a firmly established habit, whether it be good or bad, is not so easily broken, so why not form as many good ones as possible, while your material is plastic enough to be easily moulded?

For the very littlest there are stories in which beautiful hair holds the center of interest, such as:

- Rapunzel—Grimm's Fairy Tales.
- Snow White—Grimm's Fairy Tales.
- Pretty Goldilocks—Lang's Blue Fairy Tales.
- Golden Haired Children—Kuno's Turkish Fairy Tales.

If these are told in a dramatic manner they will add variety and interest to the hair lesson.

**All Sorts and Conditions of Ways of Dressing Children's Hair**

Children are the most conventional members of the human race, hence it is sheer cruelty ever to make a child look too different from his mates.

Nevertheless, there is so much variety offered nowadays in styles of hair dressing that it takes only intelligence and taste to select one that will bring out the best points in a child's face.

Fashion and good sense unite in decreeing that the bobbed head is the most practical for the small girl, as well as for the
boy. Certain types, however, look most picturesque if they have a luxuriant growth of hair flowing about their shoulders.

Needless to say, a child with a long thin face should wear her hair fluffed out on each side. A chubby, round face can stand hers bobbed and combed straight and flat about her ears, lying close to her head. The average small girl looks well with her hair parted on one side and caught with a barrette.

Those who have abnormally high foreheads will find that the bang suits them. This is usually cut straight across, though it is possible to have a bang cut with a point in front when the straight line seems too severe. In girls with a low forehead, it is quite possible that she will look better with her hair drawn back from her face and worn very like her older brother. Like her brother's, too, if the style in which the hair is cut at the back, for the present vogue seems to demand that the hair be cut to show as much of the contour of the head as possible, hence the boyish shingle, or at least a partially shingled effect.

If, however, the head is not well shaped, it is well to step out of line and have it bobbed as it was a few years back—Dutch fashion.

If a child's hair is naturally curly all so well and so good for curly hair is usually easier to dress attractively than straight hair but a child with naturally straight hair should never have it curled with curling irons, which render it dull and brittle.

The Problem of the Head Louse

BY

G. A. AUDEN, M.D., M.A.Cantab., F.R.C.P.Lond., D.P.H.Camb.

School Medical Officer, City of Birmingham.

A word of apology is perhaps necessary for the introduction as a subject for discussion of so trite a question as lousiness of the head. Yet, as a matter of fact, it is possible that lousiness is more prevalent evil in our more public money and more time of the school nursing service than any other form of minor ailment. The records of the health officers of local inspection in every borough in the kingdom reveal the continued high incidence of head infestation, and bear witness to the constant need for the control of large sections of the community regard it. The problem is, no doubt, as old as humanity itself; indeed, it has been suggested that the head louse is the oldest inhabitant who has been driven into the tightnesses and fastnesses of the head by the invading hosts of the body louse, when man lost his hirsute covering and took to the skins of animals to keep himself warm within.

A little sidelight on the common infestation is given by a poem of effectual date in the sixteenth century, of which Holmes has represented as enquiring of two fishermen the extent of their catch: "Those we caught we threw away, those we didn't catch we've thrown at us," is their easy answer. Doubtless this was a hoary chestnut, even at that date.

Professor Nuttall gives a heading to his article on the subject ("Parasitology," Vol. 10) the following apt quotation from Barbut (1752), pp. 328):

"Man, the chief lord of all animals, hath notwithstanding been made the food and ordinary abode of these vermin, who riot in his blood and sometimes colonise his body with such force and detestable offspring. What can a mean and disgusting insect as this can raise legions sufficient to render thee loathsome, and even to destroy thee? O man! where is thy vanity?"

The war has taught us much concerning the life, history and habits of this pest, and however we may use the term "head louse," it by no means the easy matter it was at one time supposed to be. This is true of both head and body louse. It is with the former that I propose to deal today.

With the absence of any proper conveniences such as hot water, basins and towels, the overcrowded state and the monumental conditions of the slums, it is not altogether surprising that many a mother gives up in despair the attempt to keep her children's heads free from infestation. Indeed, the constant reinfestation and the habituation of the lice have led many parents to believe that these are the autochthonous progeny of the skin itself. "Why she breeds them herself, if she does she ought to have removed," is a common retort to the investigator. However, it is really quite uncommon nowadays that a child which has not had some form of antilouse treatment. This has been one of the difficulties in the investigation which I have attempted to make, which are detailed below. It will be seen that in view of these difficulties, the discovery of an effective agent for the disinfection of the head would be a great social service to the community.

For such an agent to be of general value certain desiderata must be fulfilled. It should be (1) specific, (2) non-toxic, (3) non-irritating, (4) lethal or repelling to the louse, (5) have penetrating power sufficient to destroy the embryo, (6) soften and thus facilitate the removal of the nit, and lastly it must be cheap, readily accessible and easily applied, without any complicated ritual of procedure.

Professor Nuttall, in the paper above quoted, gives a very long list of insecticides which have been used for various purposes. Only a comparatively small number of these, however, conform to the above conditions, while many cannot be ruled out for use on one occasion another. Again, many of the materials described can be used for clothing only, and require more prolonged application than is possible for the head.

After trials of various substances, I have been experimenting with a soap sold under the name of "Navy Soap." Despite its name it possesses certain advantages. It was guided to the selection of this soap by the fact that its chemical and physical composition were different from those of the usual soaps purchased over the counter. It was found to possess certain advantages. It was guided to the selection of this soap by the fact that its chemical and physical composition were different from those of the usual soaps purchased over the counter. It was found to possess certain advantages. Made primarily by the action of caustic soda upon the starch, proteins, &c., contained therein, the cleansing action is different from that of the ordinary fat soap, and the colloidal products produced in its manufacture are of a different character. In the first place it does not precipitate at the same time as in combination with the calcium of the water, and there is a much less precipitation of the fatty acids in consequence. The result is that there is more fatty acid remaining in the solution, with a consequent good lather. Certain soda-starch compounds (probably $\text{[Ca}_2\text{H}_4\text{O}_6\text{Na}_4\text{O})$ are formed, which are known to be excellent emulsifiers, produce soaps of amino-acids and ammonia. Further, it contains a heavy percentage of birch tar, which appears from experience to be a most effective remedy for skin affections. The tar is presumably emulsified in the colloidal condition. It is possible also that as the birch tar contains cresols and other phenolic bodies, phenolates are produced. I am inclined to regard coal-tar derivatives as undesirable, owing to the irritation of the skin, and the well-recognised irritation of the skin caused by coal soot. Professor Nuttall wrote:

"(PP. 559): 'Further tests should evidently be made.'

"The chemistry of soaps and the colloidal conditions which are formed by their use are exceedingly complex, and not altogether understood. The cleansing properties are due in part mainly to the 'true' emulsion which the substance causes by an alteration of the surface tension and the formation of an emulsion which has an affinity for dirt, grease, &c. Many authors insist that a wetting agent and there is no 'molecular intimacy' as it is called. To be effective in destroying the louse and embryo it would seem necessary that there should be this 'true' cleansing action, and this action is accelerated by the thorough lathering of the head, which is an essential part of the process.

"The problem which confronts us is that of the nit rather than that of the louse. The nit can be dislodged by the repeated use of substances accompanied by mechanical means, such as a fine tooth comb, especially if it is emersed in a good lather. The louse, however, so persistent that even a prolonged exposure to most substances, with the exception of the mineral oils, will kill them. Moreover, the louse has a habit of..."
shamming dead, and frequently those which appear to have been killed can be found to be quite active a couple of days afterwards. Death ensuing out, therefore, is an essential part of any treatment.

The destruction of the embryo in the nit is then the chief object to be aimed at. The disinfestation of the nit, however, is a secondary consideration from a disinfection point of view. To the mother, however, the removal of the lice is often of supreme importance, as even when the hair has been treated there may still be an infestation. It is not generally recognised that the louse lays her eggs close to the scalp, and that the distance between the head and the hair to which it is attached is a measure of the age of the nit. I believe that many a parent has been prosecuted and even fined for non-compliance, because they had not scalded the hair in which the louse has long hatched out.

In order to test any disinfecting material, experiments must be carried out under certain predetermined conditions with definite control experiments. These may be summarised as follows:

1. Hairs must be taken from children who have recently been infected, and on whose heads there are living lice.

2. The hairs supporting nits must be taken immediately before and immediately after treatment with the disinfectant chosen, and incubated under identical conditions, at a temperature of 90° F., the optimum temperature for the development of the louse.

3. Nits must contain embryos in both cases. For this purpose it is necessary to examine a number of hairs from each child.

4. In any given sample of hairs one finds far more nits than living shells.

5. After incubation the nits taken before treatment should either hatch out or show evidence that the embryo has continued to develop, while the nits, after treatment, should show no evidence of continued development. Sometimes active pharyngeal movements in the contained embryo can be seen, thus affording definite evidence of life.

6. It will be seen that it is by no means easy to carry out experiments which conform to these stringent conditions. It is, moreover, not easy to cause the lice to hatch out under artificial conditions, and a good deal of experience is necessary to detect changes in the embryo indicative of death.

Another difficulty which exists is that there is no means of knowing what percentage of nits in an untreated case hatch out. In examining the nits upon hairs of hatched-out specimens, although the majority had hatched out, there was a number which did not contain fully developed embryos, which had presumably died during incubation under similar conditions, and a certain proportion of the nits do not produce living lice.

In my experiments the hairs were placed in test tubes in an electric thermostat incubator regulated to a temperature of 90° F., and the lice placed in small glass receptacles with a piece of cotton-wool. In some cases a small plug of damp cotton-wool was placed at the bottom of the tube to prevent desiccation. This, however, appeared to be unnecessary, and increased the difficulty in looking for hatched-out lice.

The results of the twelve experiments may be summarised as follows:

(a) Adult lice.—After well lathering the head for about ten minutes the majority of the lice remain motionless and could be picked off the head and rubbed off on to the towel with fair ease. When placed upon filter paper and in a glass cell they appeared to be active. However, after two hours' incubation they became inactive and moved freely, in all cases making their way into the lower compartment. The notable exception here was in the case of three experiments with live lice, all were found dead on the following day, after about sixteen to twenty hours' incubation at 90° F. This is remarkable, for the ordinary adult is extraordinarily resistant to change, and if the application is not prolonged, I have found them to revive after a drop of chloroform has been placed upon them. This is very different in the case of the lice, to which chloroform causes instantaneous death. They also survived drops of a mixture of absolute alcohol and olive oil, of such strength as to cause immediate burning sensation to the tongue or lip. It would appear, therefore, that the treatment, although not immediately fatal, does have a lethal effect upon the adult louse, and that two or three applications would be sufficient to kill a head from life by these means. A difficulty which is often found in these cases is the presence of impetiginous crusts, against which the soap is powerless.

After treating an exceptionally lousy head, the attendant complained of the large number of live lice on the towel with which the head had been rubbed. It is, therefore, worth while proceeding to take steps to kill the lice which have been detached, by boiling the towels which have been used or by pouring boiling water upon them.

(b) The nit.—I prepared a considerable number of slides of nits taken at 90° F., taken immediately before and after treatment. In some embryos survive a single treatment was proved by the hatching out of embryos, but the evidence from the microscope goes to prove that no further hatched out, as judged by the unhatched shells, from the untreated hairs. In by far the majority of slides made from treated hairs, the shell was found adherent to the bottom of the test-tube in which they had been incubated was littered with freshly hatched lice. The appearance of the unhatched shell after treatment was not always distinctive. I was at first disposed to believe that an actual degeneration of the embryo had taken place. Similar experiences, however, I have sometimes found in slides from untreated nits. There certainly seemed to be a shrinkage in the embryo in treated cases, leaving a space between the shell and the body, probably due to shrivelling of the mouth. In going through a large number of slides, without ascertaining from the label whether they had been treated before or after treatment, I found that my judgment from the physical appearances of the embryo was very generally correct. The changes in the two cases are therefore, I think, distinctly marked and peculiar.

It would appear from the above experiments that the soap in question fulfils to a considerable extent the conditions laid down. It appears to have a lethal effect on the embryo in the nit in a large number of cases, but that more than one application would be necessary to destroy viable adult lice. It immobilises the louse, but does not immediately kill it. As all lice after treatment died within twenty-four hours, it is probable that if the method were repeated several times in succession I may add that bed-bugs immersed for one minute in an ordinary solution of the soap died immediately. It is, however, a method which is not applicable and has a danger attendant upon its use, such as that inherent in use of paraffin, for instance. Paraffin, however, has had a creeping tendency that, though efficacious, it is not altogether a satisfactory de-louser. Sassafras is expensive and requires prolonged contact. I have tried Xylool varnish, which is certainly lethal to the louse as to the bed-bug, but it is inflammable and cannot be placed in the hands of the ignorant. I do not think that the method is graceful, cheap, and efficacious in any real value so far as the head is concerned. I made some experiments by adding a small quantity of ortho-chlorobenzol, which possesses a powerful disinfecting power. This substance has been tried by the U.S. Department of Agriculture (Bulletin 888, 1–15, 1920) and has been found to be effective. When applied it is an invaluable for chicken lice and dog fleas. It is also one of the ingredients of the preparation now being used to destroy the bed-bug by grinding the root of West Indian Hall. Unfortunately, however, it delathered the soap solution in some obscure way, possibly by producing carbonic acid in the surface tension. It appears, moreover, to have an untoward action on the skin of the hands somewhat similar to that produced by carbolic acid.

SCHEDULE OF FEES FOR MEDICAL AND SURGICAL TREATMENT OF INDIANS

Rendering of Accounts.

All Doctors' accounts must be rendered in triplicate to the office of the Indian Agent to whose Agency the patient belongs, on forms which may be obtained from the Department or any Indian Agent.

Expensive Procedures.

Except in cases of real emergency, Doctors are required to consult the Indian Agent or the Department before undertaking any surgical operation or other expensive procedure outside of their routine duties.

Existing Arrangements.

Any special arrangements now existing between the Department and any Medical Attendant are not intended to be affected by this Schedule of Fees.

Special Fees.

In any case requiring special skill or attention, for which the Medical Attendant considers the specified fee inadequate, it will be necessary for him to append to the account a brief description of the case, showing the number of extra visits required, dressings done, or other service rendered.

Surgical Assistants.

The services of surgical assistants are authorized only for major operations or treatments of equivalent importance, such as the reduction and fixation of a serious fracture. In cases where the fee for the treatment is not stated in this schedule to include that of the assistant an allowance of ten dollars will be made. The surgeon should include this sum in his account, and give the name of the assistant.

Norway House, Man., May 20, 1930.

Dear Sir:

I would suggest that the Indian children of the various residential and day schools be examined at least yearly. The pupils of the Residential schools are examined on admission only at the present time. Many of them remain for years and some of them get broken down in health in the schools. A yearly check up on them would enable one to weed out those likely to break down. This same examination could also be applied to the pupils in the day schools. The pupils of the public schools of British Columbia are provided with cards on which the Medical Officer records the results of his examinations and which are used annually until they leave school. I feel that if this system of examinations were instituted the results would be less sickness in the various schools.

W. N. Turpel, M.D.
Medical Superintendent.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS
CANADA

September 5th, 1930.

TO INDIAN AGENTS,
PRINCIPALS OF RESIDENTIAL SCHOOLS
AND DISPENSERS.

Complaints are received from time to time of shortages in shipments of medical supplies made by the Central Medical Stores of the Department of Pensions and National Health. The Officer in charge of the Stores states that the greatest care is taken in assembling, checking and packing these goods, and that all containers are properly sealed or strapped.

In reporting any such shortages in future kindly observe the following:

1. State the number of packages or boxes received and whether that number agrees with the freight bill.

2. State whether such packages were received and signed for in good condition. If not describe any breakages.

3. State whether all such packages were carefully unpacked and the contents checked against the delivery slip enclosed with the shipment.

Persons receiving goods by freight should never sign the freight bill without first carefully inspecting the shipment and counting the number of packages to see that the whole shipment has been received. Any packages found to be broken or leaking should be so marked on the freight bill, and report made at once to the Department. In unpacking supplies particular care should be taken to sift the packing material, as small articles may easily be overlooked. No cases or packing material should be discarded until the whole shipment has been checked with the delivery slip.

This is an important matter, and your co-operation is earnestly requested.

A.F. MacKenzie
Secretary

I have to inform you that in future when dental attention is required by the pupils at the Cecilia Jeffrey and Kenora Indian Residential Schools the work should be offered to Dr. J. A. Dean, Dentist, Kenora.

The Department's practice is to allow only necessary extractions and inexpensive fillings. In the case of temporary teeth, only extractions can be permitted. The fees, where there are several children requiring attention, are $1 per amalgam filling and 25 cents per extraction. When local anesthesia is necessary when extracting, $1 is allowed for the first tooth in each case of such patient and 25 cents for each additional tooth. Please see Dr. Dean at your convenience and, if he accepts the Department's proposal, you may arrange to have him perform the dental work recommended by the medical officer of the schools as being really necessary for the health of the pupils at each of the two above named schools.

Accounts should be in duplicate and should show the name of each pupil and the number of fillings and extractions. The accounts should be certified by you and forwarded to the Department for payment.

After consulting Dr. Dean, you should advise the Department as to whether he accepts the above offer.

You will, no doubt, have a copy of the list giving the names of the pupils requiring dental examination and treatment at each of the above schools, as prepared by Miss Olive Ings, Travelling Nurse.

CANADA GUARDS INDIANS' HEALTH
Department of Indian Affairs Maintains Health Services on all Reserves

In the care and training of Canada's Indian wards, the protection of their health is a matter of prime importance. In every province of the Dominion, reserves have been set aside for the benefit of the Indians, the Department of Indian Affairs maintains a health service whereby not only bodily ills are attended to but the Indians are trained in personal hygiene and otherwise grounded in the fundamentals of preventive medicine.

The health service of the Department of Indian Affairs is carried out for the most part by local physicians and hospitals. About 325 such physicians are employed on part-time salaries or on the new system to attend bands of Indians living in their neighbourhoods. The number of local hospitals utilized in this manner is about 200.

The permanent full-time health service of the Department is carried out by 16 Medical Superintendents, 10 Field Nurses and 7 Hospitals, located as follows:

Doctors (Full-time Physicians)
- Quebec: Bersimis, Seven Islands, and Caughnawaga.
- Ontario: Six Nations Reserve (2).
- Manitoba: Nipigon.
- Saskatchewan: File Hills and Qu'Appelle Agencies combined, and at the Battleford Agency.
- Alberta: Blackfoot Reserve, Sarcee Reserve, and at Chipewyan.
- Northwest Territories: Resolution, and Simpson.

Field Nurses
One field nurse is assigned to each of the following provinces:—Nova Scotia, New Brunswick, Quebec, Ontario, Manitoba, Saskatchewan.

Travelling Nurses
Prairie Provinces (2); British Columbia (1); Northwest Territories (1).

Departmental Hospitals
- Ontario: Lady Willington Hospital, Six Nations Reserve, Brantford, 20 beds.
- Manitoba: Norway House Hospital, 20 beds.
- Saskatchewan: File Hills Hospital, 25 beds; Qu'Appelle Hospital, 30 beds; Blood Hospital, 40 beds; Sarcee Hospital, 20 beds; Regina General, 8 beds.

The nursing staff of these hospitals numbers 21 graduate nurses. The Indians' fear of and prejudice against medical treatment have been almost wholly overcome and the hospital facilities are used at all times.

In addition to providing the services outlined above, the Department co-operates with Church missionary organizations, in the operation of hospitals and with the Provincial Governments, and the Victorian Order of Nurses in the maintenance of district nurses in many places.

DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Circular Letter 9-1E

Ottawa, March 1, 1932.

To the Indian Commissioner, Regina,
The Indian Commissioner, Victoria,
All Inspectors and Indian Agents

Indian Agents to distribute to Doctors, Nurses, Field Matrons, Dispensers and Hospitals. Further copies on request.

The department's estimates for the fiscal year 1932-33 have been greatly reduced, and it will be necessary to take measures to curtail expenditure for medical and hospital attendance during that year. Until further directed kindly be guided by the following instructions, which have been prepared with care, and which will repay careful study.

1. Epidemic Diseases

Special attention must be paid to reporting of outbreaks, quarantine of infected families, disinfection and all other measures specified in the regulations for the prevention of epidemics. Attention is directed to Circular 93-I of June 12, 1928, which, briefly summarized, states that the Indian agent is responsible to the department for these matters, acting under the advice of the departmental doctor. The regulations to be used are those of the province in which the reserve is situated.

Vaccination against smallpox is to be carried on as directed in Circular 93-IB, which gives complete directions in this connection. Special importance is attached to the prompt and complete vaccination of any band of Indians among whom or near whom smallpox appears.

Large scale immunization against diphtheria or scarlet fever by the use of toxoid or equivalent preparations is not to be undertaken without authority from the department, except in places where the majority of Indian children are already immunized. The use of antitoxin for the protection of actual contacts is, however, strongly recommended, subject to the advice of the doctor in charge.

2. Tuberculosis

It will not be possible at present to authorize admission of patients suffering from tuberculosis to sanatorium or hospital unless such patients require hospital care for relief of actual suffering; that is to say, tuberculosis in itself is not to be considered as a cause for admission to hospital or sanatorium. Special consideration may be given to patients suffering from tuberculosis of the bones and joints, where prompt treatment may prevent the formation of deformities if immediate action is taken.

As a general rule, chronic cases of tuberculous adenitis (serofulsa) are to be cared for at home.

The cost of special food for tuberculous Indians at home is borne from the medical appropriation. In recommending such cases the Indian agent must satisfy himself not only that they are required, but that the patient will himself get the benefit of them.
3. Trachoma
This affects only certain parts of the country. The directions contained in the Circular of Instructions on Trachoma, dated October 1, 1931, must be carefully followed.

4. Venereal Disease
Standing instructions on the treatment of syphilis will continue in force. The fees allowed will be as follows; and are not subject to the 10 per cent reduction provided for in section 8:

- Administration of neosalvarsan or equivalent ........ $5.00
  Note.—This drug will be supplied by the department on demand. Local purchase is not authorized. If doctors purchase locally, the department will neither reimburse them nor pay the account.

- Administration of mercury bismuth, etc. ............. 3.00
  Note.—This fee must include the supply of the drug.

- Taking of blood for Wassermann or similar test ...... 2.00

It should very rarely be necessary to keep a patient in hospital for ordinary treatment for syphilis.

Provincial clinics should be made use of whenever available.

5. Dental
Dental attention must be limited to measures for the relief of suffering. No repair work or supply of artificial teeth is authorized at present.

6. Correction of Defects—Day School Pupils
During the present school term it will be impossible to authorize operations for correction of pupils' bad dental work for pupils of day schools. An inspection of the pupils should be made as soon as the schools reopen in September, and recommendations submitted. If funds are then available, the department will endeavour to proceed with some of this work.

7. Hospital Treatment
It will be necessary to reduce hospital expenses by at least 20 per cent. The standing instructions on admissions to hospitals (50-1) are adequate and suitable, but the department considers that Indian patients in any places are admitted to hospital for trivial complaints, and kept in hospital longer than would be the case if they were either paying their own accounts or were indigent members of a white community. In the last analysis, the doctor's orders must be obeyed, but the agent should exercise careful supervision both of admissions and duration of stay in hospital.

The daily rate for the attendance of patients in the public ward of any hospital shall not exceed $2.50 per day, including such charges as those for the operating-room, X-ray, ordinary medicines, dressings, etc. The rate for a new-born child shall not exceed $1 per day. Only in the most exceptional circumstances should agents authorize the admission of a patient to hospital in connection with a sick child, and the rate charged for such a patient shall not exceed $1 per day.

The rates now paid to the following hospitals will remain in effect:
- Sacred Heart Hospital, Caughnawaga, Que.; Dynevor Hospital, Selkirk, Man.; the hospitals at Fort Smith, Fort Simpson, and Aklavik in the Northwest Territories; the hospitals in the Lesser Slave Lake Agency; the hospital at Fort Albany.
rates paid to the Lady Minto Hospitals at Cochrane and Chapleau shall be $2.25 per day.

The rates paid to hospitals located in the Williams Lake, Stuart Lake, Babine, Skeena, and Great Charlotte Agencies shall be $3.75 per day for acutely sick patients and $1.50 per day for those classed as chronic. The classification of each patient must be decided monthly by the Indian agent and the doctor.

Under ordinary circumstances there is no object in agents telegraphing to the department for authority to admit patients to hospital. Circular 90-1 gives directions for action under such circumstances, and orders that instructions should be obtained when it is proposed to send a patient out of his district to a hospital in a distant city, and in cases where the agent is at all in doubt. Henceforth the department will require a doctor's certificate for every patient admitted to hospital. The form for this certificate is laid down in Circular 90-1. It should be furnished by the doctor, signed by him, the date of admission noted, and forwarded immediately to the department, with the date of admission noted on the face, and a brief statement as to the agent's knowledge of the circumstances.

Special nurses may only be engaged under the most exceptional circumstances. The maximum rate allowed is $5 per hour, and the department will not pay any amount of accounts for special nurses' services unless the nurse has been engaged by permission of the Indian agent, on the written recommendation of the doctor, who must certify to the absolute necessity of the service.

8. Doctors' Fees

Physicians on salary, like other civil servants, will be subject to a reduction in salary of 10 per cent. Doctors on the call, or account system may make up their accounts as usual, and reduce the total by 10 per cent. In many cases, however, a doctor will find attending Indians so burdensome that he cannot attend to his own practice. In such cases, the doctor may request the Indian agent to allow him an extra fee for his services. This can be controlled in a great degree by the doctors themselves, and the department is under the necessity of asking for their constant co-operation in this connection.

In places where the Indian agent, farming instructor, field matron, or other officer is accustomed to receive calls for doctor's services, this system is to be continued.

The department, in some cases, may find it necessary to impose a limit on expenditure for the services of individual doctors.

Payments will only be made on the written recommendation of the Reserve doctor. The regulations for admission of patients to hospital are applicable in this connection, but the Indian agent should request the authority of the department unless the case is urgent.

In many places doctors on salary have been accustomed to present accounts for treatment of Indians who do not belong to the bands which they are engaged to attend, and for surgical operations, and special treatments of various kinds. All such arrangements, whether now authorized or not, must be discontinued, subject to the following provisions:

(a) Doctors who have facilities for performing major operations may address the department, through the Indian agent, and request special consideration in this respect.

(b) Doctors will be allowed extra fees for vaccination against smallpox, inoculation against typhoid fever, diphtheria, etc., and, if agreed upon in advance, for treatment of syphilis. The department wishes to encourage treatment of this kind.

(c) If any doctor considers himself to be under an undue burden by reason of calls on his services for visiting or transient Indians, he may address the department, through the Indian agent, and request special consideration.
Reports and accounts of doctors must be rendered promptly at the end of each month. Neglect in this matter may, in extreme circumstances, expose the doctor to the risk of not receiving payment.

9. Drugs

There has been a commendable reduction in the quantity of drugs used during the past fiscal year, and in many places the situation in this respect is quite satisfactory. In others, however, the department considers that great reductions might be accomplished without injury to anyone. The instructions on the first page of Drug List No. 3 are clear and specific, and must be followed in detail. To these is added the following:

(a) Alcoholic liquors will not be supplied under any circumstances whatever, nor will they be paid for if purchased locally.

(b) Requisitions must be reviewed, revised if necessary, and certified by the doctor in charge of the Reserve or Residential School. If they do not bear evidence of this close scrutiny, they will be revised at Ottawa by an officer who has no opportunity of knowing local conditions, and who will be guided largely by the per capita expenditure for this purpose.

(c) The use of cod liver oil is to be encouraged as hitherto instructed.

(d) The indiscriminate issue and use of castor oil, kidney pills, potassium chlorate tablets and many other items in the drug list is to be avoided. No drugs are to be given to Indians to take away unless it is certain that they will be taken, and that they will be needed.

(e) The privilege of local purchase of drugs is being abused in some places, in regard to kind and amount of drugs ordered, and also in regard to prices charged. Where such abuses are observed, the department will be compelled to abolish local purchase and furnish drugs from a central Government store at Ottawa.

10. General

Nothing in these instructions is to be taken as indicating that preventable suffering is to be allowed for want of funds. The appropriation for medical attendance, while greatly decreased, is sufficient to provide for actual necessities. If all officers will co-operate in preventing waste in doctors' calls, hospital attendance and drugs, no Indian need want for really necessary attendance.

While these instructions are applicable in a general way to all reserves and depots, special provisions will now be taken after they apply to medical superintendents and departmental hospitals. Further directions will be issued to these officers and institutions by the Director of Medical Services.

These instructions will take effect on April 1, 1932.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

E. L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services.

MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL

We have received the report of the survey of the Residential Schools in Saskatchewan, carried out by the Anti-Tuberculosis League of that Province.

Briefly stated that report is as follows:

1091 pupils were examined in 10 Residential Schools and one day school.

Of these, twenty-two children have open pulmonary tuberculosis, and are considered active spreaders of the disease. Of these 22, twelve are candidates for sanatorium, owing to the advanced nature of their disease. Ten might be provided for in a school specially set aside for this purpose.

A further thirty-three children have small or incipient tuberculous defects in their lungs. These may be classed as "early" cases and as potential or occasional spreaders.

Another group of eighty-five have old chronic tuberculosis. Of these sixty-four are not considered dangerous, but should be kept under observation in the schools where they now are. The remaining twenty-one are potential spreaders, and require segregation in a special school.
A final group of 17 are considered healed cases but should have occasional examination.

There are therefore:

Twelve cases for sanatorium.
Sixty-four for special school.
Eight-one for observation in their present situation, who will require more or less special treatment and food.

Of the 12 cases for sanatorium it may be expected that the parents of some, when they know the facts, will require their return home. If this accounts for, say 5, the remaining 7 will call for an expenditure of about $6,000.00 during the next year for their maintenance in sanatorium.

The sixty-four for special school accommodation present a more difficult problem. You will recall that on Dr. Ferguson's last visit here, he suggested that one Roman Catholic and one Protestant school be set apart in the Province for accommodation of pupils with milder tubercular defects who do not require sanatorium care, and who might be managed in a school provided with some special equipment and staff.

It would be necessary, therefore, to select two schools, one of each religious denomination, and to provide in the one accommodation for 17 boys and 28 girls, and in the other for 8 boys and 11 girls.

I do not suppose that any additional space would be required. There are probably two schools which have the necessary dormitory and other accommodation available. It would, however, be necessary to clear out of them a corresponding number of well pupils, by transfer to other schools, or other means.
Some additional equipment and staff would certainly be required for the two special schools, and they should be located in a place where fairly expert Tuberculosis supervision is available not too far off, and a good medical adviser close at hand.

The two schools in the area of Qu'Appelle Health Unit - Lebret and File Hills, immediately suggest themselves for this purpose. The rebuilding of Lebret furnishes an opportunity for any slight structural changes necessary to the purpose. File Hills is under excellent management and both have the best medical service and the best position for expert supervision of any schools in the Province. They are also centrally located.

I should suppose that the cost of this program would be somewhat as follows:

Maintenance of say 7 children in sanatorium... $6,000.
A nurse-teacher for each special school...... $2,400.
Extra food for 64 children at 10 cents per day each = $6,400................. $2,356.
Incidentals - equipment, etc....say........... $1,264.

Expenses of annual survey of schools estimated by the Anti-Tuberculosis League at $2,000.

$14,000.

Some years ago I formulated a plan for the discovery and segregation of Indian consumptives. While this plan proposed by Dr. Ferguson does not go as far as I should like to go, in that it does not touch the mass of infection remaining on the Reserves, nor provide for any supervision after school age, I give it my unqualified approval as the purpose for which it is designed. It provides a means whereby the Residential school may be made tuberculosis free, and whereby the children selected from them may be given a good chance of recovery.
I do not need to say that Dr. Ferguson is regarded as a leader in his field, nor that the Department is under continued pressure to bring its tuberculosis program into line with that of the Provinces. In the Province of Saskatchewan, last year, the Indian death rate from tuberculosis was 20 times that of the white population from the same cause. One quarter of the tuberculosis deaths in the Province occurred among Indians, who number 2% of the population.

The appropriation for medical services will not bear the additional expense of this program, and there is no provision for it in next year's estimates. All tuberculosis work is at a standstill for lack of funds, and there are eight other Provinces to be considered. I cannot think that a moderate appropriation for tuberculosis and trachoma work among Indians would add very substantially to the financial burden of this country.

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services.

Ottawa, July 13th, 1924.

TO ALL INDIAN AGENTS:

It has been recommended that the Department should authorize or adopt a method of treating tuberculosis among Indians by the administration of iodine, using a liquid preparation of this drug in increasing doses, by oral administration.

Having given this matter mature consideration, the Department cannot find that the claims made for this method of treatment of tuberculosis are justified. Please be advised, therefore, that the use of iodine or any of its preparations taken internally is neither authorized nor sanctioned unless specifically prescribed in writing by a qualified physician for the individual patient to whom it is to be given.

No lay person is authorized or permitted, under the terms of this instruction, to administer iodine to any Indian by mouth unless, as provided above, the medical officer has given an order in writing to the effect that iodine is to be so used and has specified in his order the exact dose to be given.

All persons who receive this instruction are requested to acknowledge its receipt to the Department at Ottawa. Indian Agents will please distribute it to every person in their agencies who have any Indians under their charge.

SIR:

I have been unable to find any Department Circular covering the procedure to be followed by the Reverend Principal of a Residential School, when a resident pupil is discharged from the School on the advice of the Department Medical Officer because of ill health.

When such a child is discharged it seems to me that the discharged pupil's Agent should be notified by the School Principal that the pupil is being sent home and mention should be made of the particular disease from which the child has been suffering, so that the Agent will be in a position to pass the information on to the Department Medical Officer in whose District the child will reside after his or her discharge.

I would suggest that a Circular to this effect be issued to all School Principals and Agents in British Columbia. At the present time the system of follow-up in connection with these cases is very haphazard ones and even in cases of pulmonary tuberculosis frequently no steps are taken to insure that even an attempt at isolation on the Reserve will be made.

MEMORANDUM:

Dr. McMillan

On November 19 I interviewed Dr. John Phair, Chief Health Officer for Ontario and discussed with him health education in the Indian schools and obtained literature on the subject.

P.E. Moore, M.D.,
Ass't. Sup't. of Medical Services.
Memorandum:

DR. STONE:

A delegation representing the Anglican, Roman Catholic, United and Presbyterian Churches interviewed the Minister on November 21, last, with respect to the restoration of the 5% deduction in payment of per capita grants to residential schools. The Minister of Justice and the Minister of Labour were associated with the Minister in this interview.

I may state that immediately following the presentation of their case on the restoration of per capita grants, a memorandum was submitted to the Minister by the delegation, in which the Churches deal with educational policy and the health and general welfare of the Indian population. The following excerpt, for your information, is taken from this memorandum:

"SOME URGENT NEEDS. Of the more urgent needs for pupils in either the Day or Residential class of School, one of the most pressing is that of regular visits from dental clinics. The following extract from the report of a dentist after visiting certain schools furnishes strong evidence of this need:

"Upon first examination of scholars in these schools deplorable oral conditions were found, temporary and permanent teeth with crowns broken down and gone, abscessed roots, gingivitis, great deposits of tartar and teeth that had never been brushed. One thing was noticeable and that was that the children coming from beyond the civilized area seemed to have less carious teeth than did their cousins who were living on the borderland or in civilized areas. One would infer from this that the cruder diet of those removed from stores and civilization had a bearing on the teeth.

"Children in these schools range in age from five to sixteen or seventeen (the Government sets an age limit which I think, is sixteen) boys seem to predominate in numbers. There is a great prevelency of tuberculosis amongst the Indians and in all likelihood this was a distinct factor in tooth decay. Many of the worst cases were amongst the juniors; oral hygiene was unknown to all; temporary teeth that had not exfoliated were left to misguide or impact incoming permanents; mastication in many cases was an improbability as much pain would ensue upon the least pressure. Altogether it would be almost impossible to visualize conditions more neglected and deplorable.

"Bearing instructions from the authorities at Ottawa that no temporary teeth were to be filled, no filling materials to be used but cement and amalgam and that no prophylaxis would be paid for, I commenced work. My first visit lasted for one day, and what a day it was!

I found -
I found no scholar who escaped the forceps and after ten hours of almost continuous work over three hundred teeth had found a resting place in our improvised canteen. Three weeks later I again visited this school and spent the best part of three days filling the teeth and giving the needed prophylactic work (for which I received no remuneration). I felt that it would be impossible to instill into the minds of the youngsters the need for brushing their teeth if they were not started on the right road, so therefore, gave them a cleaning up. Instructions were given to the staff to assist in the follow-up work by insisting on toothbrush drill and from subsequent visits one would judge that this was done.....

"The Principals and staffs of the schools visited were loud in their praise of effects gained. Absence from classes on account of pulpititis, etc., had decreased from several cases daily to nil. The children were able to eat and enjoy their meals and were, in many instances, putting on weight. They were more attentive in the classroom and better results were being attained generally."

The Minister, in replying to these representations in a letter dated December 12, 1938, states in part:

"The suggestion you make that greater provision should be made for dental work at our schools is one that will be brought immediately to the attention of the Superintendent of Medical Services."

It is unnecessary to add that I should welcome an opportunity to discuss this matter with you and with Mr. Phelan any time at your convenience.

[Signature]

Dear Sir,

I beg to report that due to an epidemic of Poliomyelitis (infantile paralysis) and Encephalomyelitis (sleeping sickness) now prevalent in the Province of Alberta all public schools are to remain closed until September 15th, 1941.

I have discussed the situation with Dr. A.C. McGugan, Provincial director of communicable diseases who informed me that our Indian Schools would come under this order. I then discussed it with Dr. J. H. Conroy, M.D., and he stated that it was his wish that the Edmonton and Youville schools remain closed until the public schools opened.

Acting upon the advice of both Doctor Conroy and Doctor McGugan I have informed the Principals of the Edmonton and Youville Residential Schools that the schools would not open until September 15th, 1941.

Two weeks ago Doctor Conroy asked me to issue instructions to the Indians not to allow their children under the age of 17 years to go to the City of Edmonton, these instructions were issued to the Indians.

While discussing the situation with the Rev. J. F. Woodsworth, Principal of the Edmonton Residential School he stated that his school would have approximately $750.00 overhead expenses from August 29th when the school was to have opened and September 15th, and asked if the Department would assist in paying part of this expense; I informed Mr. Woodsworth that I could not answer that question but that I would mention it in my report to you.

Respectfully submitted,

I am Sir,

Memorandum:

Dr. Scott,

The Health of Animals Branch, Department of Agriculture, tests for tuberculosis, without cost, the milch cows at Indian residential schools. Only a few of the schools have "Accredited" herds (6 registered animals) and the Department of Agriculture pays compensation for these animals that will only when the herd is accredited. Dear Sir:

The Department of Indian Affairs has several schools in the dried out areas of the Western Provinces. All of them have farms attached with herds either of dairy or beef cattle if not both.

These herds under ordinary conditions are a great help to the schools both as producers of milk and beef and as a means of training the children that are attending school in the art of farming and cattle raising. This year, however, due to the drought, these herds are a great burden to each school as all fodder and grain for their upkeep have to be bought at prices which are almost prohibitive. The schools under our jurisdiction have either killed or sold the beef cattle which they had last fall and have only kept such dairy cattle as were essential for the producing of milk for the school children. But even with this drastic reduction in the number of cattle kept, the cost of hay and grain is still greater than the schools can meet out of the grant.

We find it, therefore, necessary to apply to the Department for special consideration of each school in the dried out area which is so handicapped. We would suggest that the Department supply to these schools the same amount of hay and grain that the Governments of the Western Provinces are supplying to the farmers situated in the same areas. By adopting this method of relief, we believe that no criticism of the Department could be made as it would be doing for the Indians just what the Provincial Governments are doing for the white population living in the same areas and under the same circumstances.

We submit our case in all confidence and hope that the Department will give it favorable consideration.

Yours very truly,

Dear Sir:

In reply to your letter of the 17th instant, in connection with fodder conditions at the St. Phillip's Residential School of this Agency, I beg to report as follows:

1. Number of cattle kept - 19
2. Number used for milk supply - 12 at present time, which is about the average for the year.
3. Condition of the cattle - Not very good, owing to poor feed.
4. Amount of hay and fodder necessary to carry them through - about 75 tons.
5. Amount of hay and feed raised by the school this year - 13 tons of hay.
6. Amount of hay and feed purchased or will be necessary to purchase this year - About 22 tons of hay purchased, and 15 tons hay still to be purchased. These figures are given me by the Reverend Principal of the school and I think he should have considerably more than this. The milk cows are not in fit condition for milk. They are being fed mostly on wheat straw, with some hay, but not sufficient to milk more than half what their capacity would be under good feed.
7. To purchase the feed necessary to carry the cattle through, owing to drought conditions, has cost approximately $300.00, but, as stated above, the cattle are not being fed as they should be fed.
8. The only cattle disposed of owing to shortage of feed, were 2 cows and 5 calves, butchered for use in the school.

I think the arrangement at this school, by which the farm land is rented on shares with a neighboring white farmer, and not worked by the school, is not the best possible arrangement, and the feed situation would have been better this year if the school had had the whole crop. I have spoken to the Reverend Principal regarding this, and the question of his taking over the whole of the farming operations, but he does not feel inclined to do so. He says the number of elders at the school would not be able to do the whole of the farm work, and that he would have to hire a considerable amount of extra assistance to do it, also that he has not the stable room to carry enough horses to...
do the farm work and his finances at the school are so low that he could not afford to take chances on the expenses of the whole of the farm for fear of the possibility of crop failures.

The Reverend Principal also informs me that the other school principals with whom he has been in contact, inform him that the operation of the school farms causes a loss in most cases, unless there is a particularly good crop. If this is the case it does not speak very well of farming, as a whole, in Saskatchewan or the management of the schools, because the schools should be able to employ their labour when necessary to employ any, and they all have some older Indian boys to perform some of it.

It is so long since I have seen a paying crop at an Indian school that I do not feel in a position to argue this point, as I saw seven successive non-productive crops at the two residential schools at the Crocus Lake Agency, before coming here, and I have not seen one since, but it seems to me that the school farms in the northern part of the Province must pay good returns, and they should here, under average conditions. The renting arrangement at the St. Philip's school has been the custom for many years, and I would not like to be responsible for insisting upon the change, because there is always the possibility of a failure and I think any drastic change should be the choice of the principal and the responsibility for success or failure, also his.

These observations, while not directly connected with the information you have asked, are somewhat related to the matter in question, and I would like you to consider them, for what they are worth, and I would like to have your opinion.
