MEMORANDUM:

DR. MCGILL,

In a letter to the Department dated December 9, 1937, Reverend Father J. O. Plourde, O.M.I., General Superintendent of Oblate Catholic Indian Missions, submits, for our consideration, a request received by him, for special financial assistance, from a group of schools situated in the drought stricken area of the province of Saskatchewan.

In response to instructions, Inspector Robertson, in co-operation with Indian agents, has made an investigation of conditions existing at six residential schools operated under the auspices of the Oblate Order in Saskatchewan. Dr. Robertson estimates that the loss sustained at these schools, as the result of drought, shortage of hay, oats, vegetables, etc., at $9,080. All surplus stock at these institutions was disposed of early in the fall of last year. Father Plourde in his letter states:

"We would suggest that the Department supply to these schools the same amount of hay and grain that the governments of the western provinces are supplying to the farmers situated in the same areas."

There are in the province of Saskatchewan nine residential schools operated under the auspices of the Catholic Church. I have not obtained from Inspector Robertson a report on conditions at the other schools. It is my opinion that all the residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan, with the exception of one or two in the northern section of the province, are urgently in need of financial
financial assistance.

Reverend T. B. R. Westgate, D.D., Field Secretary, M.S.C.C., has not yet submitted a special request on behalf of the three schools operated by the Anglican Church in Saskatchewan. But, in a letter sent forward by him to the Department dated December 21, 1937, he deals in a general way with the difficulties experienced by the Anglican Church in securing the funds necessary to operate their residential schools.

Dr. Westgate states:

"Our Society's overdraft at the bank, on account of our Indian residential schools, is $52,324.35. This year, 1937, it is now estimated that our expenditures will exceed all receipts by $18,000. This increase is very largely due to the increase in the cost of flour, other cereals and commodities generally."

Dr. Cochrane, representing the United Church, interviewed me at my office early in November. Dr. Cochrane informed me that the Home Mission Board of the United Church were experiencing the utmost difficulty in finding the money necessary to support their residential schools. At that time I made arrangements whereby fifty per cent of the per capita grants due to the United Church for the current quarter was paid in advance. In fact, we have found it necessary in recent years to make such advances to all the churches.

I was not aware, until recently, that the churches were experiencing so much difficulty in financing their residential schools. Our failure to restore the five per cent deduction in per capita grants, together with the substantial increase that has taken place during the last year in the price of supplies, has, no doubt, contributed to this condition.

It is my opinion that conditions in the province of Saskatchewan
of Saskatchewan are very serious and that immediate steps should be taken to assist the churches in maintaining their schools there in a reasonable state of efficiency. Dr. Robertson, in reference to the condition of the cattle at the St. Philips Residential School, states:

"It is noted from the agent's report that these cattle are in poor condition. It is his opinion that they are not getting enough feed, owing to drought conditions, the schools being unable to purchase the grain necessary for feed."

In view of these conditions, may I recommend the immediate payment to the church authorities responsible for the administration of residential schools in Saskatchewan of a grant equal to $5.00 per pupil. The total authorized pupilage in the residential schools in the province is 1,675. The special grant I suggest would amount to $8,375. This sum may appear to be somewhat inadequate, but it represents the maximum grant we can make out of the current year's appropriation. If a grant equal to this amount is authorized, the utmost care will have to be exercised in the authorization of expenditures for repairs and supplies at Indian day and residential schools during the 2½ months remaining in the present fiscal year.

The necessity for the restoration of the five per cent deduction made in the per capita grants is a matter that should be given very careful and very sympathetic consideration.

Supt. of Welfare & Training.

Memorandum:

THE DEPUTY MINISTER,

I am sending forward herewith a Report to Council, containing a recommendation for the payment of a special grant to residential schools in the province of Saskatchewan. You will note that this grant is being paid at the rate of $5.00 a head on an authorized enrolment of 1615 pupils.

Careful consideration has been given to the suggestion contained in Mr. Jackson's memorandum of January 14th, that this additional grant should be restricted to the schools in Saskatchewan which have been directly affected by drought conditions in the province. It is exceedingly difficult, however, to select a school which, in our judgment, is not in urgent need of special financial assistance. For example, in the Battleford agency, northwestern section of the province - where the Thunderchild Residential School is located, relief costs during the period April 1 to December 31 have increased almost 100% over the expenditures for the same period of last year. Relief figures for the Carlton agency show a similar increase. The Principals of the two or three residential schools which have not suffered directly as the result of drought conditions have experienced the utmost difficulty in securing the necessary supply of meat, vegetables, milk, etc., and have only succeeded in securing these at prices substantially higher than the prevailing prices of last year. I am convinced, therefore, that it would be more equitable and certainly more in accord with the actual needs of these schools if the grant was made as now suggested, on a pupilage basis.

Dear Sir:

As you doubtless are aware the National Dairy Cattle Committee, under the chairmanship of Dr. E.S. Archibald, functions under the National Advisory Committee on Agricultural Services in an advisory capacity in the interests of the dairy cattle industry. It has five subcommittees as follows: Sterility Problems, Bang's Disease and Mastitis, Artificial Insemination, Nutrition, and Stable Management, each of which is active at the present time.

In addition to the normal work of this Committee, and its sub-committees, Dr. Archibald has suggested that the Committee might perform a very useful service and fill a great need in acting, if possible, as a two way "clearing house" of information relating to various phases of dairy cattle production, and a coordinating link among the various institutional herds in Canada. The idea behind this suggestion is that it is felt that among these institutional herds, as for example, Dominion Experimental Farms, agricultural colleges and schools, penitentiaries and jails, hospitals and mental institutions, Indian Affairs' institutions, Veterans' Affairs projects, etc., etc., there is lying fallow a wealth of data and experience relating to problems and practices which could be of inestimable value to all concerned if collected, analyzed, and used. A consolidation of information of a practical nature, which naturally would be collected on a voluntary basis and used in a confidential manner, would be of value to the Committee in making recommendations of a national character, to the institutional superintendents in the efficient operation of their farms and herds, and to the Canadian dairy cattle industry at large.

Many examples might be given of the value of such a proposal for all concerned. One which was cited at a recent meeting was the case of three institutional farms and herds adjacent to one another and under different governmental administrations in Canada carrying out many quite different practices in farm management and herd operation, each of which might have benefited by the experience and good management factors of the others if known and applied. Such matters under consideration might be those of finding out the nature, extent, locality and best methods of overcoming breeding troubles, mastitis, acetomelia, etc.; experiences in the efficient growing, putting up, and feeding of legume silage and how such a feed fits into various cropping practices; efficiency and utilization of labour for milk production; problems and experience in relation to costs of different types of barns, layout, equipment, etc.; location, use and suitability of surplus feeds, breeding stock, etc.; and many others.
It is proposed first of all to compile as complete a list as possible of Canadian institutional dairy herds and when this is made to attempt to obtain the voluntary co-operation of the managers or superintendents in direct charge, and send them a practical questionnaire dealing with such information as outlined above. An attempt would be made to analyze such information on a collective basis and utilize it to the very best advantage. The continuance of such a scheme would naturally depend on the reception and progress made of such an undertaking.

We should be very glad of your candid opinion of the above proposal and any suggestions you may care to offer as to its practicability and feasibility. In order to compile a list we would appreciate your giving the names of any dairy herds, either purebred or grade, that may be under your jurisdiction, the addresses and names of the men in direct charge of them, together with your permission to communicate with them. I may add that no commitment in any way other than outlined in this letter is involved.

I would appreciate a reply at your earliest convenience.

Yours very truly,

C.B. MacKenzie
Secretary, National Dairy Cattle Committee.

Correspondence re inquiry to be held in connection with each death.
DEPARTMENT OF INDIAN AFFAIRS

Memorandum of an inquiry into the cause and circumstances of the death of ........................................................., Pupil No. .......................

of the ........................................ Indian Residential School at ........................................,

who died at ........................................ (place) on ........................................ 19 .....

INSTRUCTIONS

When a pupil of an Indian Residential School dies, the Principal is required to inform the Indian Agent at once.

On receipt of the Principal's notice the Indian Agent shall convene a Board of Inquiry, consisting of himself as Chairman, the Principal of the Residential School, and the Medical Officer who attended the deceased pupil. These members of the Board shall, in each other's presence, complete this memorandum, which shall then be forwarded to the Department of Indian Affairs, Ottawa, in one copy.

The Board of Inquiry shall, if at all practicable assemble within 48 hours of the pupil's death.

The parents or guardians of the deceased pupil shall be given notice of this inquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative. They or their representative shall be asked if they wish to make a statement. In the event of their so wishing, their statement shall be attached to the report. The inquiry, however, shall not be delayed more than 72 hours after the time at which it would otherwise be held, to enable them to attend it.

If the Indian Agent is located at such a distance from the school as to make it impracticable for him to attend the Board, he shall request a responsible local resident to act for him. A suitable person for this duty would be a Justice of the Peace or a member of the Royal Canadian Mounted or Provincial Police. A more or less permanent arrangement of this kind might be necessary in some cases. The Department is prepared to pay a reasonable fee for this duty, on the Agent's recommendation. The report of the Board, in any case, must reach the Department through the Indian Agent's office.

This inquiry is not designed to take the place of, or prevent, any other inquiry, including an inquest, which may be required by law.

If the pupil died as the result of an accident, the Indian Agent is required to take the statements of the witnesses of the accident, and attach them to this memorandum.

To Indian Agents and Principals of Indian Residential Schools:

It has been decided that, in future, an enquiry be held immediately following the death of a pupil of an Indian residential school who dies while enrolled as a pupil of the school. This action will protect both the school authorities and departmental officials and, at the same time, will give the Department full information regarding the circumstances attending the death of any pupil in a residential school.

The enclosed form, containing the necessary instructions, should be completed and forwarded to the Department.

If the deceased pupil dies in hospital, at a distance from the school, under the care of the physician or surgeon who is in attendance at the hospital, a clinical report of the patient's illness and death in the hospital is to be secured and attached to the memorandum regarding the enquiry into the pupil's death.

It is not the Department's intention to pay travelling expenses for Indian parents in order that they may be present at the enquiry; but, as pointed out on the form, the parents or guardians of the deceased pupil should be given notice of the enquiry and be permitted to attend it or to send a representative.

Copies of this letter, as well as copies of the enclosed form, are being forwarded to the Principals of Indian residential schools. In future, you should keep a supply of these forms in your office.

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

Dear Sir:

With reference to your letter of June 15th, 1911, file No. 273510-5, re school at Baccumains.

I beg to report that I had an interview with Father Boily and Chief Paul Ross. The location of the school was not definitely settled, Father Boily desiring to call a joint meeting of the whites and Indians to determine the location. The Chief insisted on the school being on the reserve, and if built on the reserve, it was agreed that the location would be on the rising knoll just inside of the eastern line fence and about 225 yards from the river, and on band property.

There are about sixteen children of eligible school age of Indian parentage, and Father Boily asked for as liberal grant as possible stating that a grant was now given of .40 per scholar per month by the department which amounted to between $70. and $80. per annum. An annual grant paid quarterly would be preferable of say $100. per year. It is the Fathers intention to build the school by the labour of both the white and Indian population and by subscription, this would, of course, mean a joint ownership and be under the control of the Father and Indian Agent.
After discussing the matter of ownership with the Father it was agreed that the school could not be closed or removed without the consent of the Indian Department and that an annual rental for the ground of $1.00 per year be paid. This agreement should be made in writing and signed by the Father, when, or before the department gives the grant.

Father Boily is going to write the department the result of his next meeting as to location of school and until he is heard from again no further action is necessary. I may say the Chief seemed unalterably opposed to the school unless built on Band property.

Your obedient servant,

At a meeting of the Indians of the Escoumains reserve and of their immediate white neighbours, it was resolved:

1. To build a school-house on the land of the Indian reserve in common, the white people supplying the necessary material. And the said white people and Indians shall do the work of construction in common. The white people will not trespass on the land of the said reserve.

2. Each of these races will pay its share for the maintenance of a teacher. The white people will provide her board and lodging and what remains of her salary, which will be about $150, perhaps more. We wish to have a good teacher.

3. Each of the two parties shall furnish their share of firewood for the said school in the severe season.

4. The parish priest of Escoumains shall have the supreme control of this school; he shall settle the difficulties. This school shall be neither Indian nor white, but mixed, in order to prevent disputes in future.

Done in general meeting this 3rd day of July, 1911, and signed in the presence of us, the undersigned parish priest of Escoumains, and in the presence of each other, these presents having first been read over.

Paul Ross, chief

Parliament at its last session voted a salary of $300.00 for the teacher of the girls' school, and this amount will be available from the time the school is in operation.

The stone buildings formerly occupied by...
Employing the Grand Trunk Railway on the Ross will no doubt afford ample accommodation for school purposes both for boys and for girls. Caugnawagan Excited.

The people of the little Indian village of Caugnawagan are just now violently excited over a question which has raised quite a great deal of bad blood amongst the several factions in that locality. Some years ago, the Government promised each such of $500, to be applied annually for educational purposes among the Indians. This plan was promised, but for some reason or other these people have not yet to this present day received any of the money placed at their disposition. Now, however, the question of how to get this money has become a burning question amongst the otherwise quietly-disposed Indians. It appears that a considerable portion of the fact, the better part of the community, had decided to form the Catholic St. Joseph's mission religious community at Lachine, and send three of their number to attend the mission school there. At the same time, possess themselves of the Government grant. This suggestion has been met with resistance from a few Indians who seem to be decidedly against the interference of the Catholic education. The anti's have succeeded in raising a terrible tempest in the neighborhood, and are pressing for the closure of the village and safety of the sums if they should come into the place.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott,

In pursuance of your instructions I visited the Caughnawaga Village to look into the complaint made by the Caughnawaga Council that the fence recently erected around the Girls' School enclosed land which should not have been enclosed. The investigation took place at the Council House and was attended by nearly one hundred members of the band.

I had before me the conveyance of the lot from James Phillips to the Superintendent General for the purpose of a school. In this conveyance the lot is described as bounded "in front by the Main Street, on the east by another street, on the south by the lot belonging to the heirs of Isaac Jacobs and on the west by the present school property." It is with respect to the eastern boundary in particular "another street", that the complaint is raised. It is difficult to say just what was regarded as the western limits of this street at this place. The street is not very wide elsewhere. The eastern end of Mr. Phillips's house was about four feet west of the eastern end of the present school building and he claims that he regarded that as the eastern end of his lot. When he owned it, there was a fence from the southeast corner of his house running south to the fortification wall. This fence and the western end of his house formed his eastern boundary. After this lot was
purchased for a school there was a fence erected at the eastern end running north and south about four feet east of the old building just on the line of the present school building. There never was to the knowledge of the oldest members present any fence farther east than this. It does not appear to me that the road would come as far west as this fence, but as this lot is at the four corners and was not fenced, the public apparently was accustomed to take a short course around this corner. It was established that this corner had always been open for the public and was used as a gathering place for announcements, as it is just across the way from the front of the Church, and the Indians feel aggrieved at having it enclosed and being deprived of it. The fence recently erected on the east side of the school is over forty feet from the end of the building. The Council on behalf of the Indians and themselves desired to have it placed near the foot of the steps being a few feet from the building.

After discussing the matter with the four members of the Council who were present they concurred that if the fence was placed at a point four feet west of the flag pole and parallel with the eastern wall of the school building which would be over twenty-two feet from the wall, and if the angle of the fence on the north side was made less sharp they would be satisfied.

Mr. Delisle, another member of the Council, was unable to be present. I went, however, to see him with respect to this adjustment and with respect to the claim of his mother to some land on the southeast corner within the recently erected fence. Mr. Delisle was rather obdurate and contended that the Indians would not be satisfied with the fence four feet west of the flag pole. Finally he agreed to the fence being placed six feet west of the
flag pole which would leave over twenty feet between it and the school building. Mr. Delisle has considerable influence with the members of the band and I thought it advisable that he should be satisfied with whatever proposals were made.

Mrs. Delisle, a daughter of Angus Jacobs, whose lands are referred to in the conveyance from James Phillips as bounding Phillips' lot on the south, claims a rectangular piece of land between the east limit of the lot conveyed by Phillips, and the travelled part of the road described as being bounded on the west by a line running northerly from the north point of the east end of the fortification wall at right angles to the said wall a distance of twenty-six (26) feet; and on the north by a line running easterly through this point parallel with the fortification wall to the sidewalk on the westerly side of the travelled road. Mrs. Delisle has no conveyance of this property. It has never been enclosed.

Mithel Montour, an old Councillor, stated that some years ago there was a question raised as to Mrs. Delisle's northern boundary and that he representing the Council with the late Agent Brossard indicated where the line was commonly supposed to be. There does not appear to be any record of this to show whether this land was regularly set apart for her or not. There is no reference to it as being on the eastern boundary of the lot sold by Phillips. I cannot say that Mrs. Delisle has no claim neither can I say that her claim was satisfactorily established. Mr. Delisle on behalf of his mother agreed, in consideration of the sum of $25, to have his mother give a quit claim deed of any interest she may have to land within the hereinafter proposed boundary.

The following is a copy of the
memorandum signed by Mr. Delisle setting forth the boundaries and the consideration proposed:

"1. Front fence of school to be placed six feet west of the flag pole parallel with the eastern wall of school."

"2. North fence to be changed to run from the first post east of the eastern gate post to a point in the fence now existing where said fence is intersected by the proposed front fence.

"A line is to be drawn from the north corner of the east end of wall at right angles to the wall a distance of 20 feet northerly; a line is to be drawn from this point easterly to the sidewalk at right angles; a line is then to be drawn from the middle of the end of the wall to the point where the last mentioned line intersects the sidewalk."

"Mr. and Mrs. Delisle quit claim and surrender whatever rights she or he may have to lands within the last mentioned line on the south and the proposed line on the east 6 feet west of Flagpole to the Superintendent General for the sum of twenty-five dollars."

I think that the fence on the east half and the south easterly corner might properly be removed and placed on the lines as above set forth in No.1 and No.2, respectively, without special detriment to the school grounds. I would recommend that this be done and that the sum of $25.00 be paid to Mr. and Mrs. Delisle in satisfaction of any claim that they may have to property within these lines.

I am not in sympathy with the proposed change of the north fence as set forth in No.2 above. This change would destroy the symmetry of the boundaries and would narrow up the grounds at a place where there is at present little enough space between the school building and the fence. The roadway is the same width at the corner which it has been suggested should be changed as it is at the north westerly corner of the lot and I do not think that the present fence is any encroachment on the road allowance or that the public will suffer any inconvenience by the fence being where it now stands.

September 11, 1928.

Memorandum:

Mr. Scott.

Mr. Chene has estimated the cost of fencing the grounds at the new Senior Day School, Caughnawaga, at $1485. The cedar posts would have to be placed in solid rock and then filled in with concrete. As you will remember, we secured several large lots for this school, so that we would eventually have a good playground, not only for the children, but for community purposes. Considerable grading will have to be done in the future, and I am taking note for next year's estimates. Mr. Chene's estimate includes an ornamental gate on the main highway.

The funds can be found in the Appropriation, for the fencing this year, and I have to recommend that you give your authority to have the work undertaken. Mr. Chene suggests that it be done by contract.

Some additional grading should be done this year around the building, and I wish to recommend that $600 be allowed for this purpose - the work to be done by day labour, under the supervision of Mr. Robert, the efficient engineer-caretaker at the school.

Sept. 14, 1928.

My dear Sir,

Another scholastic year has started with a record most pleasing and encouraging. Could it be otherwise with the splendid school provided by the Department. That the Senior School can rival with any school, even in larger Montana, is what every visitor has said and which I am proud to repeat especially to the officials of the Department of Indian Affairs. Assuredly, the building and its very fine class equipments are worthy of praise. The school rooms are most attractive and inviting, 156 girls and 198 boys were registered the first day. All are in the best of spirits and the year promises to be one of assiduity and application.

I deem it my duty to speak of the grounds around the Senior School which are used as a pasture; the corners of the school also in a dreadful condition, as the animals brush against it and loosen the bricks. The newly white steps in the front would need another cleaning. You can imagine the condition of the grounds, so consequently, the pupils cannot play outside. Do you not think a cheap wire fence around the grounds with a large gate for the front entrance would be advisable.

Yours respectfully,

[Signature]
Principal.

Mr. Russell T. Ferrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.
SIR,

I beg to inform you that an amount of $600.00 is now available for the continuation of the grading of the ground surrounding the Central School at Laughingstone. I understand that Mr. Roberts, the Overseer of the school, already had charge of this kind of work before, and suggest that you request him to undertake this additional grading and levelling work, providing it will not interfere in any way with his duties as Overseer of the Government schools, for which the Department is willing to pay him for the time he actually spends on the work. The wages to be paid to the women are to be those allowed on similar work by the contractors for the building, and it should be understood with the foreman that all possible care is to be taken when grading, in order to protect life and property.

I am advised that the Departmental Engineer has already explained to Mr. Roberts the nature of the work to be carried out, for which the expenditure is provided.

With reference to the erection of a fence around the school grounds, I beg to say that this matter is not under consideration, and I shall further advise you at a later date as to the Department's decision concerning this addition I wrote.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Oct. 29, 1926.

MEMORANDUM

As per instructions I made arrangements last week when at Caughnawaga in company with Indian Agent Letourneau for the erection of a fence around the Senior School lot. Mr. Alphonse Barasolou of Laprairie has been requested to supervise this work which will be performed by day labour. I will proceed with this fencing during the course of this week. The rate of wages set by him is $10.00 per working day, including board and travelling expenses.

The fencing will consist of 6" peeled cedar posts, with galvanized wire fencing 50" high, made of 9 bar stays, 16½" apart, with a top and bottom railing made of 2 x 4" dressed studding. I would suggest for the front fencing, which is 50' long, that one double gate with two turnstiles built of ornamental steel be installed, similar to that erected around the church property with posts built of brick instead of stone.

The foreman has requested that a surveyor be sent to Caughnawaga as early as possible to give him the exact location of the proposed fence. I cannot attend to this owing to the disappearance of posts and old fences. I may say that Mr. White of this Department made a survey of this school lot at the time it was acquired.

On the East side of the Senior School at Caughnawaga when the road is put on the outer side of Lot 91, the fence will be within 25 feet of the corner of the school. This is not desirable.

Je viens de rencontrer à Caughnawaga M. White,
Ingénieur du Département qui vient de tracer les alignements pour la clôture qui doit être construite autour du terrain de l'école Senior.

En attendant de recevoir du Département le plan avec la longueur de la clôture à construire, je vous prie de bien vouloir m'autoriser à faire l'achat des poteaux. Après m'être enquis des fournisseurs de poteaux de clôtures, je constate qu'à ce temps-ci de l'année il est impossible d'avoir des poteaux de grosseurs uniformes en quantité suffisante, excepté cependant de M. Jacques Bourdon, à Laprairie, qui peut fournir à l'entrepreneur, M. A. Barsalou, 20 poteaux de 10 pieds de longueur pour les places basses sur le terrain en plus d'environ 180 autres poteaux de 7 pieds nécessaires pour entourer complètement ce terrain. Ces poteaux ont de 5 à 6 pouces au petit bout, ce que je crois de grosseur suffisante. Le prix de ces poteaux sont de $1.50 pour les 20 de 10 pieds et les autres sont à $1.00 le poteau.

Comme je viens de vous le dire, il semble impossible de s'en procurer ailleurs que chez M. Bourdon à Laprairie. RE: Caughnawaga school fence.

Dear Sir:

I am pleased to send you herewith a copy of the accounts due to Mr. Alphonse Barsalou from Laprairie, who obtained the contract to build a fence around the ground of the school of Caughnawaga.

I understand that that work was given by contract per day; it is to say that Mr. Barsalou was to drill the holes in the rock to put the posts, and then buy the posts and buy anything that he needs for the said work at the expense of your Department.

The understanding was that he was going to have for himself $1.00 per hour, and for his employees .50¢ per hour, to do the work, this amount to cover not only the work but the cost of transportation of Mr. Barsalou and his employees to Caughnawaga, morning and night.

You will find herewith a copy of all these accounts for which Mr. Barsalou held himself responsible. All his employees have been paid by himself.

As far as the posts are considered, it was a little hard to obtain the required number of posts from the same place and at the same time; he had to buy a certain number from here and there in the vicinity; that would explain why he did not produce the bill from each place; but he has bought 188 posts of eight feet, for $1.00 each and you will find all these posts either installed or ready to be, on the ground of the school.
Chambre des Communes
Canada.
Montreal, January 16th, 1929.

Mr. A.F. MacKenzie,
Acting Deputy Minister & Secretary,
Ottawa.

You will find also a bill for carters to carry the material and a bill from Mr. Lawrence McGee for sundries and also a bill from Mr. O. Brisson, blacksmith of Laprairie, the total amounting to the sum of $990.60.

You will easily find out that owing to the difficulties of the work to be done, that the whole thing has been done speedily and economically, and in the same way as would have done a good "Pater Familias".

As Mr. Barsalou is now sick in bed, and is anxious to receive his well earned money, I would like very much that you see that these bills be paid at your earliest convenience.

Sir,

I beg to inform you that you may purchase the balance of the cedar posts required for the completion of the fencing around the School grounds at the Senior School at Gagniawaga, etc., and arrange also for the installation of these posts and the ones remaining on the grounds. The work is to be carried out by day labour under your personal supervision, with the assistance of Mr. Robert as foreman, who I understand is familiar with the nature of the work which remains to be performed for the improvement of this school property.

You may obtain competitive prices from local dealers in Montreal for the furnishing of the following materials and place the order with the firm quoting the lowest price delivered on the ground. The necessary fencing made of No 9 heavy galvanized steel wire, 48" high with uprights 22" apart, having at least 6 horizontal bars at equal spacing.

1600 feet of No 9 galv. barb wire to be placed on top of the above mentioned fencing together with the necessary staples and other fasteners required.

1 single drive gate similar to those installed at other schools in Gagniawaga, this to be erected at the east side of the lot at the end of the road.

5 turnstiles built of iron pipe strongly constructed to be erected on metal posts anchored in concrete base. The turnstiles and gate to be installed where agreed upon with the Superior of the School.

I have the honour to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 21st inst., concerning the proposal of completing the work to the fence surrounding the property of the Senior School at Caughnawaga.

During my visit at Caughnawaga, on the 25th Inst., I met Mr. Robert about this matter and he did not want to give me a final reply that day concerning his acceptance of taking charge of that work. However, he let me understand that he was very busy at other work and that he wanted to wait until the 10th of June next to start the fence; he would then be able to give it all the necessary attention; to this I replied that if the work could be terminated during the course of June, I thought the Department would be satisfied.

I take this occasion to ask you if it would not be preferable to install a gate of the turnstile kind on the East side of the land instead of a single gate like those installed at present at the other schools; for that reason that the single gate would be left open when the turnstile would be more satisfactory.

Should I understand, when you mention 5 turnstiles, that in this number will be also comprised those that will be installed by the front part? or if the plan of the erected front of this building includes at all any turnstile. In this case one (only) turnstile on the East side would

CLÔTURE Invincible POUR LA FERME

Personne n'apprécie autant que le cultivateur l'importance d'une "bonne lignée" ; c'est par elle qu'il juge des sujets d'élevage et des graines de semence.

Quand il s'agit de clôture la même précaution dans le choix conduit tout naturellement à la clôture Invincible.

Comme manufacturiers de la clôture Invincible, The Steel Company of Canada Limited est fière de pouvoir offrir au cultivateur canadien un produit, dont la fabrication entière a été contrôlée par ses propres moyens de confiance à partir du choix du minerai de fer.

C'est une œuvre d'ingénierie "enregistrée" et nous avons pourtant une bonne "lignée" ; nos mécaniciens ont éprouvé le minerai et les autres matériaux ; nos chimistes ont fait des analyses du fer en guesse à sa sortie des hauts-fourneaux ; nos chimistes continuent les analyses pendant la transformation du fer en acier dans les fournaisses Open Hearth, et quand le lingot est coulé au laminage, nous savons exactement ce que nous avons et la lignée des animaux de race est connue de l'éleveur renommé. En continuant la comparaison entre les deux du même côté les bêtes de race avec la clôture Invincible et de l'autre les troupeaux communs avec les clôtures manufacturées de billettes ou de tiges achetées un peu partout, même à l'étranger, au hasard des bas prix.

En employant la clôture Invincible cette année encore vous affirmeriez une sage coutume dans les achats de clôture, et votre geste confirmerait l'expérience de la majorité des cultivateurs canadiens, à qui, depuis vingt ans la clôture Invincible donne satisfaction complète et durable.

LE FIL

La clôture Invincible est fabriquée de notre propre fil d'acier Open Hearth, pur, dur et fort — le fil d'acier reconnu être le mieux qualifié pour faire de la bonne clôture.

Le minerai, le coke et la pierre à chaux sont d'abord chargés dans les hauts-fourneaux et là ils sont transformés en fer en guesse, qui à son tour dans les fournaisses Open Hearth est raffiné en acier. Le fer en guesse en plus de contenir du fer contient aussi d'autres éléments, à savoir le soufre et le phosphore, qui, si leur concentration est trop importante ou si certains affecte la qualité de l'acier et par le procédé Open Hearth leurs influences sont dosées ou éliminées au besoin. Le soufre et le phosphore tendent à amoindrir la qualité de l'acier — le procédé Open Hearth les nullifie tous deux et produit un acier plus fort, plus dur, plus pur, et d'autant mieux préservé de la rouille que son uniformité retient la galvanisation sur tous les points.

Quand l'acier a été mis à point dans les fournaisses Open Hearth il est coulé en lingots et ensuite subit les différents procédés de laminage, étant successivement bloom, billette et tige. Enfin il est treillé à froid, galvanisé et tissé en clôture. Pendant chacune de ces opérations une inspection incessante et rigoureuse veille à la qualité.

Les recherches, les efforts et les succès d'un personnel averti et consciencieux pendant cinquante ans nous valent une installation de grande efficacité qui est une garantie pour l'acheteur des clôtures Invincible. Le fil de la clôture Invincible est de la grosseur la plus pratique pour le Canada et il est recouvert d'une épaisse couche du meilleur zinc qui lui assure la durée sous les plus exigeantes conditions atmosphériques.

Le Tissage

La clôture est surtout exposée à trois catégories d'épreuves : les multiples changements de température ; l'état rocailleux, montagneux ou inégal du sol ; les chocs brusques et les tensions violentes ; toutes ces épreuves exigent de l'élasticité dans la construction de la clôture. Pour la clôture Invincible les fils larges sont enduits (voir vignette). Cette ondulation donne au fil l'élasticité voulue pour "prêter" au besoin et assez de ressort pour revenir d'aplomb quand la tension est passée.

Le Nœud

Le nœud est une des parties vitales d'une bonne clôture, car en plus de bien tenir les fils en place, il doit se prêter à une grande flexibilité. Par sa formation serrée, le nœud Invincible a une prise solide sur les fils. Il ne conserve aucune humidité qui produirait de la rouille et il est de même jauge que les fils qu'il relie. C'est une force là où certaines clôtures ont leur point faible.

Barrières Invincible Galvanisées à Chaud

Brevetés en 1914 et 1920

Au lieu de se complaire dans la haute qualité des produits Stelco et Invincible, nos ingénieurs recherchent constamment des améliorations. Au cours de l'année écoulée, l'adoption de notre tuyau décapé a valu aux barrières Invincible une autre amélioration très sensible.

Pour la fabrication des cadres des barrières on n'emploie que du tuyau décapé, et ce, pour donner à la galvanisation une dureté encore plus grande. On appelle tuyau décapé parce qu'on a enlevé les écaillles de la surface que de l'érosion ont été enlevées. Les surfaces parfaitement lisses obtenues de la sorte permettent à la galvanisation de s'appliquer uniformément sur toute la surface de la barrière sans le risque de voir des écaillles se détacher, mettant le tuyau à nu et l'exposant à la rouille.

Depuis longtemps, les barrières Invincible sont renommées pour leur force sans égaliser, pour leur durabilité et leur "galvanisation à chaud". Avec le grand avantage que leur ajoutent le tuyau décapé et la supériorité incontestable des coins carrés, le choix de l'acheteur est tout indiqué.

Grillage pour les Rats Musqués

Robert G. Hodgson, l'expert dans l'élevage d'animaux à fourrure, écrit dans un article sur les rats musqués: "Pour entreprendre cet élevage d'une manière sérieuse, il faut tout d'abord un endroit où les animaux vivent comme à l'état sauvage et où ils soient protégés contre leurs ennemis naturels: vision, renard, belette et loutre." Une clôture appro- priée est donc ce qui s'impose au début et c'est pratiquement la seule défense requise.

Détails

La clôture ordinaire pour les rats musqués consiste en un grillage de quatre pieds et d'une tôle galvanisée d'un pied de hauteur. Un pied du grillage est enfoui dans le sol, trois pieds se posent au-dessus, consolidés par la tôle. Les plaques de tôle perforées à chaque bout, se raccordent au moyen de rivets. Le grillage est ensuite fixé dans le bas par un crochet de grillage, qui consiste en un fil d'acier Open Hearth de la jauge 15½ galvanisé avant ou après le tissage.

Le grillage varie en hauteur, de 1½ pied à 6 pieds. Les rouleaux ordinaires mesurent cent pieds de longueur. La tôle galvanisée est de la jauge 28 et mesure 1 pied x 10 pieds.

Barrières Invincible

La partie la plus importante d'une clôture est la barrière, car si elle est d'un dessin quelconque ou de construction négligée ou d'un posage au petit bonheur, elle causera toutes sortes d'ennuis. C'est d'ailleurs une constatation que n'importe qui peut faire, car les barrières sont destinées à plus d'abus que toute autre partie de la clôture. En faisant le plan d'une barrière, il faut viser à la solidité et au fonctionnement facile, parce que, une fois installée, elle doit être quasiment indestructible.

Les barrières Invincible à mailles de chaîne sont faites de tuyau décapé et galvanisé de 1½ pouce D.E. (diamètre extérieur). Les coins, en fonte malléable, rivés au cadre, servent d'appui pour les gonds. Le cadre des barrières acquiert une plus grande rigidité grâce à deux tuyaux décapés et galvanisés de 1½ pouce D.E., croisant à angle droit de ces tuyaux et formant le cadre, sont fait de pièces de fonte malléable préparées avec soin. Toutes les ferrures sont galva-nisées à chaud. Il y a des barrières à mailles de chaîne dont les coins sont soudés, mais nous ne recommandons pas beaucoup ce genre pour les largueurs de 6 pieds et plus.

Les cadres des petites barrières sont faits de tuyau décapé et galvanisé de 1½ D.E. avec coins et tirants soudés. Toutes les barrières Invincible à mailles de chaîne sont finies de grillage Invincible galvanisé avant ou après le tissage et avec ou sans fil barbelé, selon la clôture. On entend, par largeur d'une barrière l'espace entre les poteaux, car nous dénissions quelques pouces pour les gonds et le loquet que, d'ailleurs, nous fournissons. L'on ajoute des décorations appropriées sur les barrières de parterre.

**Le posage**

Pour la permanence et la rigidité nous recommandons que tous les poteaux soient posés dans le béton. Nous sommes en mesure d'entreprendre le posage au complet ou de fournir à prix nominal les services d'un contremaître qualifié.

L'expérience nous a appris à mettre tous les poteaux de ligne dans une base en béton mesurant environ 8 pouces de diamètre dans le haut et s'élargissant graduellement jusqu'à 16 pouces au fond, à $3\frac{1}{2}$ pieds de profondeur; pour les poteaux des bords, des barrières et des coins, faire une fondation d'environ 10 pouces de diamètre dans le haut, 18 pouces dans le bas et $3\frac{1}{2}$ pieds de profondeur. Nous suggérons aussi le mélange suivant pour obtenir les meilleurs résultats: une partie de ciment; deux parties de gros sable à béton; 4 parties de pierre concassée de $\frac{3}{4}$ de pouce.

La clôture Invincible à mailles de chaîne est facilement raccordée d'une longueur à l'autre et sans que le joint paraisse. SPECIFICATIONS

SECURITY

CHAIN LINK FENCING

END and CORNER POSTS are made from standard hot galvanized steel tubing 3½" O. D. for the heavy, high fences, 2½" O. D. for the middle weight or lower styles, and 2¼" O. D. for the lighter gauge fences.

LINE POSTS are made from standard hot galvanized 2½" O. D. steel tubing for the heavy high fences, 1¾" O. D. for medium weight and 1½" O. D. for light gauge fences.

TOP RAILING is made from standard hot galvanized steel tubing 1½" O. D. for the heavy fences, 1¼" O. D. for the medium weight and lighter fences.

POST TOPS are hot galvanized and fitted over the post to keep out water.

EXTENSION ARMS and Barb Wires are hot galvanized and are carried by a heavy lug from MALLEABLE post tops. Three strands of 4 point barb wire are carried on these receding Extension Arms, making a formidable barrier. When, for appearance, on lawns or private property the arms are not desired, a single barb wire may be placed at the inside of the post tops.

FABRIC

SECURITY Chain Link Fabric is made from the best Open Hearth Steel Wire and hot galvanized by the most up to date method.

The wire for all SECURITY fencing is made from the ore to the finished product in the Sydney plants of the British Empire Steel Corporation with which this Company is affiliated.

St. Constant, July 15th, 1928

Following my letter of the 2nd inst., concerning the wire to be used for the fence now being erected around the grounds of the Union school at Baughnawaga, I enclose herewith a letter from the Security Fence Co. Ltd. of Montreal dated the 13th inst., submitting a price list of their different kinds of wire fences.

As I had already remarked in my last letter to the Dept., I do not think I should recommend the use of the wire described in the second paragraph of your letter of the 21st of May last, for the reason I do not believe it strong enough.

The prices already given to the Dept. by the East Steel Co. for style "L" and "LP" being 16¢ and 28¢ and those submitted by the Security Fence & being 14¢ and 17¢, I believe I should recommend that the Security Fence be favored with the order. It is however of a different style which is to be taken into consideration and which I leave to your own choice.

I am now informed that style "Chain Link" is generally employed around the grounds intended for school work. This "Chain Link" style is also sold by the Security Fence Co. at 26¢ per lin. ft. The cost price would be about $575.00. Taking the strength of the material into consideration, I seem to me that the "Chain Link" 2" mesh would be most acceptable and I wish to recommend it to the Department.

Yours truly,

(Signed) Lawrence LeTourneau

Dear Sir:

Mr. James Jacobs owner of Village Holding No. 461 has in the past suffered damages caused by the pupils attending the Eastern School, which is located on Holding No. 460. The pupils who are playing football and baseball have to go and get their ball when it goes on Jacob's garden and I am personally aware that this Indian suffered considerable losses by the children's action.

It is believed that if a higher fence was erected between the school lot and that of Jacobs, it would remedy the situation. The line between the school lot and that of Jacobs is of 193. The present fence is of only four feet high and at present is almost non-existent having been erected over 25 years ago.

I would ask you to take the matter of building a new fence into consideration; this before the month of May in order to protect the garden of this Indian when it is planted.

Yours very truly,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa, Ont.

Dear Sir;-

I have your letter of the 31st of March last, dealing with the erection of a fence between the yard of the Eastern School and Lot No.461 of this Village, the property of James Jacobs.

The fence would be of eight feet high consisting of two four feet strips of mesh wire. This would prevent the pupils to jump over the fence and go over the garden, where for several years, the crop has been spoiled.

MEMORANDUM

for the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs:

Re Red Rock School, Nipigon.

John Deschamps, former teacher of the Red Rock school was dismissed on the recommendation of Mr Agent Donnelly for having closed the school without authority and for repeated acts of carelessness and inattention to duty. The Rev. Father Specht also asked for his removal, and was informed that Deschamps would not be retained and that he was at liberty to nominate his successor.

The question of the appointment of teachers for Roman Catholic Mission schools around Lake Superior was settled with Father Specht who is in charge of these missions. In July '26, the Department agreeing to accept his nominees for the position of teachers of Indian schools in his mission at an annual salary of $350 each on the understanding that the persons recommended by him were of suitable qualifications for such positions and that their appointments were not to take place until the approval of the Department had been obtained. All applications to embody previous experience and qualifications and to be submitted through the local Agent of the Department.

With regard to the dismissal of such teachers,-
before their removal the Department to be fully advised as to
the cause which calls for the same, when, if considered suffi-
cient, their dismissal would receive its sanction. Father
Specht was requested to at once report any incompetency or
inattention on the part of teachers.

A communication was received in December last from
Chief Deschamps, of the Red Rock Band (father of the late teach-
er) asking for his re-appointment and he was told that the
Department could not see its way to comply with his request.

Father Specht has not submitted the name of a suc-

partment as a school on this Reserve is not urgently needed

Dear Sir,

I have just received your letter dated 19 November No. 1538/2 in which it is stated that the Department does not see its way to re-open this school. I am very much grieved to hear that especially when I see that there are schools kept open that have a fewer number of school children than we do here. The number of children attending is enough to justify the re-opening of this school and the number will be greatly increased with the opening of spring when the Indians will have returned from their winter hunt by all means so we cannot have our school re-opened. As Chief of this Band I most respectfully insist on it. Why have we been put to the trouble
Creating a school house, if it is allowed to remain unoccupied and not used for the purpose for which it was intended, should it please you to re-open our school. I may say that we are not prepared to accept as teachers the nominees of the Father Spedale. We would rather nominate our own teacher subject, of course, to the approval of the Dept. It seems to me quite evident that the Father Spedale and I may be some other are at the bottom of all this. The Rev. Gentleman has never been in sympathy with us in having a school of our own. He wishes to bring us to the Lake Union school, some five or six miles distant, which for our children would be an utter impossibility from its great distance, and the great danger of crossing the lake, especially in stormy weather, so we can readily perceive that our request is both reasonable and just.

As Chief of the Band, I claim the right to protect the interests of my people, to seek their welfare and endeavor to promote whatever means that may tend to improve them intellectually otherwise. As regards their spiritual affairs, the priest can whose province it is can attend to that, but I will take no part in the matter of education and the secular affairs being competent to attend to that matter and the Department with respectful deference to the Dept.
Some also add that this is the proper place for the Indian Reserve. There is good land and abundance of wood also. It is far enough removed from the railroad to be free from molestation from the disrespectful white trash who come in contact with our people. Demoralizing and degrading them to the lowest level. The Lord Nelson Mission is a most disputable place owing to its proximity to the degraded whites. We wish to live in peace and decency to have our own school and educate ourselves so that we can success fully manage our own affairs on a par with our white brothers. Yes, dear sir, we must have our school re-opened. There is a pressing necessity for it and now is the season for it when we who remain at home have the most time to devote to the cultivation of the mind. I feel to be most respectful but I must say that I am firmly determined to agitate this question until our request is granted.

Please write me soon.

Yours obediently,

Pierre Deschamps,

Dear Mr. Pyeatt:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 30th ultimo, stating that the Chief of the Red Rock Band of Indians, at Terence, has written you with reference to opening the Indian school at that point next spring, and you ask whether arrangements can be made so that this can be done.

In reply I have to say that on the 17th of February 1896 Mr. Donnelly, the late Agent, reported that the teacher of this school, John Deschamps, son of Chief Deschamps, had closed the school without authority before Christmas 1895, and had gone to work at a pulp wood camp. Mr. Donnelly reported that Deschamps was very unsatisfactory; and as the attendance of the pupils was very poor in winter, he recommended that the school remain closed until there was some guarantee.
guarantee of a better attendance, and the services of a more competent teacher could be obtained.

Deschamps was, however, given another trial from the 1st of April 1896 for one quarter; but, as he again proved unsatisfactory, his services were dispersed with at the end of that term.

Chief Deschamps has repeatedly urged the Department to re-appoint his son, but as apparently the only reason why the Chief desired that the school should be re-opened was in order that his son should be employed, and as the Department did not think the attendance of the children justified it, no money for the salary of a teacher was voted for the present fiscal year. The salary was $250.

When the Chief realized that the Department would not re-appoint his son he recommended Mr. James Mackay for the position. Although it was not considered advisable to re-open the school, enquiries were made as to Mr. Mackay's qualifications and character, with the result that he was found to be unsatisfactory.

If Chief Deschamps is honest in his desire that
the school at Red Rock be re-opened for the benefit of the children, and not in order that a friend of his may receive the appointment, or an assurance being received from him that he will not raise any objection to the nominee of the Rev. Father Specht (with whom an arrangement was made by the Department in 1896 that he should nominate teachers for Indian schools within his district) an amount to cover the salary of the teacher, which has been included in the next estimates, and no more will need to open the school after the beginning of the next fiscal year.

Mr. Paget calls attention to the need of a school at Red Rock in the Fort William Agency.

Red Rock is situated where the Nepigon River empties into Lake Helen. Ottawa, Oct. 17, 1922.

Sir:-

A request has been received from Chief Joseph Salt, of the Red Rock Reserve, for the re-opening of a school on that reserve. He states that the Indians of the Red Rock Band held a meeting and wish to know why there is not a school on the reserve instead of at Lake Helen Mission. He gives the names of 12 children of school age who, he states, are residing on the Red Rock Reserve, and he requests authority to build or remodel a large building to be used as a school house.

As you are aware, we recently provided a rental for the use of the building which is used for school purposes at Lake Helen. The last return received from this school shows an enrolment of 16 pupils. This school is not on a reserve and the Indians living there should be residing on their own reserve at Red Rock.

As there would appear to be a sufficient number of children on the Red Rock Reserve to warrant a school being reopened, I have to request that you will state, as soon as possible, what it would cost to remodel and fit up for school purposes the building referred to by Chief Salt. You should also state whether, in your opinion, a school should be reopened for the benefit of the children of the Red Rock Reserve. It is considered that it would be only fair to the Indians of this reserve to provide them with a school as there are, no doubt, sufficient children at both Red Rock and Lake Helen Mission to have schools operated at both points.

I shall be pleased to have your views and full particulars as to the cost of fitting up the building referred to for school purposes at the Red Rock Reserve, as we are desirous of providing educational facilities for the Indian children of this reserve, in view of the fact that these Indians are complying with the wishes of the Department and residing on their own reserve.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Acting Asst. Deputy & Secretary.

Sir:

re. File 9-8-1, of October 22nd, 1924.

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 22nd ultimo; in reply I wish to state, that I visited the Red Rock Indian Reserve on October 29th, 1924.

The School at the above mentioned Reserve is located about two miles from the Red Rock Reserve where the majority of the Band live, and have been living for the last 35 years. There are a few families living at the Reserve which is approximately five miles from the town of Nipigon, Ont.

There is no building at the Reserve that could be used for school purposes, and no accommodation for a teacher, as there is no road leading from the Reserve to Nipigon, and the majority of the Indians leave their reserve in the winter, to trap. I would strongly recommend leaving this matter as it stands. Upon investigating, I find there are only eight children of school age living on the Reserve.

The present school at Lake Helen where the majority of the Indians live, is only a mile and one half from Nipigon, Ont., which makes it very convenient for the Teacher.

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

In November last, we, the Anglican Indians of the Shesegwanning Reserve, received a communication, stating that your Department would recognize the school on this reserve conducted under the auspices of the Church of England, and would allow the old school building to be used for this school. It was at the time understood by us that in the near future steps would be taken to provide more adequate school accommodation. As, however, we have heard nothing further about the matter, we beg respectfully to submit for your consideration the following facts:

The building has previously been condemned, at a time when, I believe, the average attendance
considerably less than it is in our school at the present time.

There are nineteen children on the register of the school, and the average attendance for the last year has been nearly eighteen.

The interior dimensions of the school-room are 23 ft x 14 ft x 7 ft, and the space is quite inadequate for the number of children attending.

There is no cloak room or other extra accommodation, with the exception of a small storm porch. There is no place for the storing of firewood, gardening tools, etc.

Cooking and other special instruction cannot be given at the school, but the children have to go outside to private dwellings for such purposes.

There is no provision of any kind for living quarters for the teacher.

In view of the above facts, we would ask you to give your consideration to the question of providing more suitable school premises, in order that the

MEMORANDUM.

Mr. Scott,

The Church of England members of the Oseehiguaning Band sent in a petition sometime ago for the erection of a combined school-house and teacher's residence. Mr. Agent Baxter was asked to obtain a resolution from the band authorizing the required expenditure to be taken from their funds. Mr. Baxter has reported that as the majority of the voting members of the band are Roman Catholics they have declined to pass the required resolution.

There is no doubt that a new school building is needed, as the one in which the school is now held was condemned long ago and is totally unfit for the purpose, besides which there is no accommodation for a teacher on the reserve.

Sub-section 3 of Section 97 of the Indian Act provides that the Protestant or Catholic minority of any band may with the approval of and under regulations made by the Governor in Council have a separate school established on the reserve. The Department has sanctioned the operation of the Protestant School there and in order that
it may be properly carried on a suitable building should be erected. Sub-section 2 of Section 59 of the Indian Act gives the Governor General in Council power to construct and repair school buildings and, as the Shehegwaning Band have a capital of $59,294.95 to their credit, they could well afford to put a new school-house there. If you are not prepared to make a recommendation to Council to take any portion of their capital for this purpose money should be provided in the estimates for putting up a combined school-house and teacher's residence. The Roman Catholic school on the reserve cost $5,600.15, but this building is large enough to accommodate all the pupils there. A smaller building would meet the requirements of the Protestant school and if the same class of building is put up it would cost in the neighbourhood of $4,000.00, as it is a very out-of-the-way place to get material and labour.

Aim.—The purpose of this distribution is to encourage pupils and teachers to interest themselves in the beautifying of the school buildings and grounds and to facilitate the carrying out of the work. The results of such work are twofold: in the first place the school work and the pupils' education are helped, and in the second place the status of the school is raised in the community and the interest in and support of education are increased.

Children's Clubs.—The distribution is not restricted to school-ground improvement. Schools at which children may be organized into clubs, or at which a class or group of pupils may have planned together to carry on similar work at home, are permitted to participate under this scheme; pupils, teachers and parents joining in the practical work with the pupils' permission also. It is naturally expected that the pupils' experiences will be put to educational uses in the future.

Materials, Sour Out.—The Schools' Division tries to procure the highest quality of supplies for the distribution at fair rates. It does not seek to supply cheap material. While it does not guarantee the material, it strives to protect schools against failures and loss. The selection made is of such hardy things as should do well under rather adverse conditions.

Vines.—The vines are hardy except the Boston Ivy; it should not be bought for northern counties. The Clematis Punctata has masses of small white flowers, not large purple flowers. The Dutchman's Pipe has fine large leaves. The Rambler Roses are two of the best known varieties.

Gladiolus.—The flowers of the Gladiolus make a splendid show. A few bed of them in front of a school would make a fine sight in August or the beginning of September. The bulbs are planted from April to July and lifted after the fall frosts, to be stored inside for the winter.

Dahlia.—Dahlias produce their flowers in September and October. There are three types of flowers, viz., Garden, Decorative and Show. The tubers are planted in the ground when the weather becomes warm. Before hard frosts they are lifted, dried a little and stored inside for the winter.

Aim.—In arranging for the sale of agricultural books to rural schools, the Schools' Division seeks to have rural school libraries adapted to the needs and interests of the communities, for whose advantage these libraries have been formed.

Why should there not be an agricultural book shelf in every Ontario rural school?
Why should there not be a good selection of books and bulletins relating to the chief business of the community?
Why should there not be encouragement for the boys and girls to read about things that are of direct interest and use?
Why should the work of the school not fit in, in every way, with the interests and needs of the whole community?

Agricultural Books.—It is suggested that every country school have a shelf on which bulletins and a few of the best agricultural books should be kept, and the pupils encouraged to use them in spare periods, and to take them home. The shelf should be readily accessible. An agricultural bulletin board for displaying pictures, newspaper clippings, exercises, new weeds, etc., might be placed alongside the shelf. Some of the pupils might make these.

Agriculture in the One-Teacher Schools.—The agricultural teaching in a one-teacher rural school is not aimed primarily at giving young pupils a large fund of technical agricultural instruction. If a teacher succeeds in interesting her pupils in their agricultural environment, using this interest in the school work, makes them observant and inquiring, inspiring them to read and acquire knowledge for themselves; she has done much in adjusting the country school to meet the needs of country life.

Reading Should be Encouraged.—While there is no text-book prescribed for the work in agriculture, it is important that pupils should be interested in reading for themselves upon agricultural topics, reproducing the best books, bulletins and periodicals, and trained to use them in connection with their class studies, debates, and experiments. The agricultural books should not be kept behind locked doors, but rather where pupils can get them without much trouble.

The aim is not to make Book Farmers but Reading Farmers. Not to teach agriculture from books only, but from nature also! Not one book but all good reading matter!

The teaching of agriculture is developing through Nature Study and Children's Gardening. The work should result in an inquiring mind and a desire to read!

Dear Sir,

The Catholic Indians of the Shi Shigawin Reserve have been told that the Department proposes to build a school for the few Anglican families of this Reserve. As we have often done in the past, we again protest with all our energy against the erection of another school with the Band's money.

Three years ago, at the request of these same Anglican Indians, your Department has built, with our money, a large school near the farms of those Anglican Indians, and out of the central or overwhelming Catholic population. The year after, those same Anglican Indians have stolen away our Town Hall, with your last approval, and used it near their house, to use it as a school; and now our majority is about to be despised again by those few Indians who use our money to build school for their own children—its five of them children have been taken to the fingewash Home, the others are too few to have a school of their own—we know that there are some political influence in that affair.

But we ask for British fair play and the execution of the Indian Act.

Very Respectfully Yours,

Gentlemen:

I beg to draw your attention to the condition of school-house on the Sheshegwaning Reserve (Anglican section) where I have been engaged to teach.

The building is in a very dilapidated condition totally unfit for the purpose.

When I was engaged to come here, it was on the understanding that a suitable school residence was to be built this year. I am now living in the house of Chief Risamivina, who very unsatisfactorily moved out that I might have a house fit myself & family until the new building is erected. He is at great inconvenience and therefore I am placed in an uncomfortable position.

We have sixteen pupils on the roll and I have two little girls which have to stay at home as there is no accommodation for them. They are rather delicate & I would not care to have them crowded in that building. The roof leaks, the windows are failing to pieces and do not let in sufficient light, the place is draughty, ceiling just above one's head in fact, nothing is satisfactory.

The scholars here are bright intelligent, clever and quick to learn. One of them took first prize for penmanship at Silverwater Fair this year, competing against five schools including Silverwater.

The whole section of the Anglican Indians here are very progressive, anxious to learn, and are very desirable citizens.
It is absurd to teach "Hygiene" in a little dark, stuffy hole like that! In fact, it is a model building "for killing children."

I feel sure that the Department will attend to this matter at once, now I have brought it before them.

I remain, Gentlemen,

Yours respectfully,

Edwin Weller.

Mr. Scott,

Application has been made for improvements to the Sheshegwaning C. E. Indian School, Manitoba, to provide temporary accommodation for the pupils attending this school, pending a favourable time when funds will be available for the erection of a permanent building for their use.

There are at this time 19 pupils enrolled, with an average attendance of 14 during three-quarters of last year, which would probably be increased if accommodation were adequate.

The building occupied is that formerly used as an R. C. school, (moved from the old position to the present site near R. C. school) and is small and in poor condition, being 17 x 22 with 7 ft. ceiling, and provides air-space accommodation for 10 pupils only, while the floor area accommodates 22. The building is reported to be in very
very poor condition; yet, as this is the only building available, and the school apparently a necessity, and the outlay necessary to make temporary improvements, small, I would recommend for your consideration that an expenditure of $250.00 be authorized to provide this extension, and any additional expenditure incurred beyond this amount, to be provided by the Indians who are accommodated. The improvements suggested are, an extension to the present building of 12 x 17 with roof plate 10 feet above floor line, and the present building raised to that height, which will provide regulation accommodation for twenty-one children.

The materials could be purchased and deposited on the grounds and the frame work extension erected during this fiscal year; the balance about $75 to $100 would have to be provided from 1916-17 vote.

Gentlemen:

I beg to call your attention to the unsatisfactory state of affairs re. the Anglican School here. The Indians being unable to get the Dept. to move in the matter last winter added a piece on to the end of present building. This was never intended to be a permanent job, but something had to be done at that time as the building could not accommodate the number of pupils.

The Dept. cannot possibly understand the condition of the building. It is absolutely past repair unfit for a school building. When it blows, the noise of flapping tar paper is so great I cannot hear pupils and be answer questions when it rains. Water pours in through the roof & I have to keep moving things from place to place to keep them dry.

It seems very strange that while we are double the number of pupils attending school than are attending the Roman C. school, they have a large up-to-date commodious school, while we have a small dilapidated old shed. We would like to know what the
Dept. has in mind re. this matter as certainly must be done this summer.

I have to tramp half a mile or more across fields to get to the school, which is no joke in the winter, where the snow piles up in drifts about four feet deep. One has to break a new track every time as the wind fills it in a few minutes after. Many a time last winter I was quite delayed after breaking a track to the school.

Again, the late chief John Kigamwina, moved out of the house to make room for me & my family, thinking it would not be for long. He is crowded into a little house with two rooms. Himself, wife, wife's mother, the son & two girls - six persons in two small rooms. You can imagine how mean it makes me feel. It is impossible to stamp out consumption that way.

I do not wish to give the Dept. any unnecessary trouble. My aim is to do all I can both for the Indians & to help the Dept. where possible.

We have fifteen on the roll & my own making seventeen & there will be more September.
As far as the teacher's dwelling is concerned, I would put up with almost anything so long as it was on the school grounds. A small four-roomed log house would suit me. It's cheap to build. It would cost very little.

I would like to know, as I will have to make some other arrangements in a house in the near future.

Mr. D. Sampson has asked me to mention that he has never been paid for taking the census of the Indian families two years in succession, although he received word from the Dept. that he should be paid.

Also that there has been no money paid for alteration to building, nor for lumber, nor for cord wood or cleaner.

He asked me to request that these monies be forwarded without delay, trusting to be favoured with an early reply, stating that these matters will be attended to without delay.

Remain, Gentlemen,

Your obediently,
Exxon Weeks.
Teacher

At the Protestant school, the teacher Mr. Weeks appears to be progressive and reported 19 pupils in attendance with two pupils preparing for the Entrance examination next year.

The school garden is very good but as no permanent location is yet made the fencing etc. is only temporary but all the growth is splendid.

The building is the old discarded schoolhouse with the end knocked out and a rough addition made to it. This addition is covered with tar paper and the rain gets through causing great inconvenience.

It would appear as if the Department should take some steps at an early date to provide a suitable building for the Protestant portion of the band. Such a building should have at least three rooms for the accommodation of the teacher. At present Mr. Weeks is living in a house of an Indian which has been loaned to him, the Indian living in a small shack in the meantime. The Indian is desirous of having his house to live in and the teacher must find another place but did not know where he could obtain one. If he is to keep the school open some provision must be made at once for a house for him.

His Royal Highness,
The Governor General in Council,

The undersigned has the honour to report that a school-house situated on the Sheshawangan Indian reserve, on the Manitoulin Islands, has become so dilapidated that it is necessary to replace the same by a new one; and, as it is extremely difficult for the teacher to find accommodation in any of the Indians' houses, it is essential that quarters be provided for him. In order to meet the requirements, the Department decided to call for tenders, receivable up to noon of the 31st August, 1916, for the erection of the combined school-house and teacher's residence, and the following were received:

J. C. Kennedy, Owen Sound, Ont., $5890.00
Neil McMartin, Little Current, Ont., 4675.00
George Stevin, Gore Bay, Ont., 3652.00

The undersigned would recommend, pursuant to the requirements of subsection 2, of section 36, of the Public Works Act, that the contract for the erection of the above mentioned building be awarded to George Stevin, the lowest tenderer, for the amount of his tender as above cited, namely, $3652.00, the same to be charged, under the provisions of section 89 of the Indian Act, to the capital at the credit of the Sheshawangan band, which amounts to $63,108.66. The architect of the Department reports that Mr. Stevin's tender is somewhat below his estimate for the work to be done but that it is a fair and reasonable price.

Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs.

Re new school building I understand that specification calls for a stone foundation.

The Indians all favour a concrete foundation, as do also the contractor & myself; being stronger, quicker more durable.

Dear Sir,

The Indians here at this place are asking for some changes in their school. First, that the outside entrance to the basement goes down straight and a porch be built over it, which is very necessary. The basement is only down about four feet in the ground, at that depth the snow hardens. Second, they want the eastern part in side for no doubt it would freeze up in the winter time. There is a corner...
in under kitchen where basement could be put. I moved one window six feet away from corner in order to leave space for eastern. They also want a pipe and pump fitted. Third. They want a bedroom over school room in attic. This can be also done but a little of the stair-way would show in school room up near the ceiling. Running partition out six or seven feet from each plate, spiked and strapped from joice to
rafter would support the ceiling and put in some extra long joists. Put a window in the rear gable end of school. All the changes they asked for would cost about five hundred dollars. I told the Indians what it cost and they were all satisfied. I made no provisions for material for extra work and I would have to draw it about forty miles on wagons. If same work will all be up this week and I must know.
at once whether those changes will be made or not as it would give me considerable trouble if I had to make the changes when the work is well on the way. Hoping to hear from you by return mail addressed to Silverwater.
