This is impossible. The rooms are already too small after allowing for staircase. I fail to see how you can divide the remaining space into two rooms. Every room in the house is uncomfortably small with the whole space above schoolroom going to waste. I fail to see any reason why there should not be at least one room over school-room where two rooms could be arranged quite easily. We positively must have three bedrooms ought to have four. In the residence at the other school here, the whole of the space above schoolroom is used; most of the dwelling being over the school. I am sure that if you will consider this matter you will agree with me that the accommodation is inadequate. The extra room over school-room is very necessary. As work is proceeding very rapidly I would feel grateful if you would consider this.
without delay.

obliged,

Dear Sir:

The new school building.

I would strongly advise you to send a reliable & competent man from Ottawa to examine this building & to check off the work with specification. Specifications have been entirely ignored & the work that has been done is very poor & unsatisfactory.

For instance:
- Ground floor is not laid diagonally as specified.
- In house is soft wood instead of hard wood.
- There is but one layer of tar paper under outside sheathing & also under shingles.
- Specification calls for two layers outside & two layers of felt under shingles.
- Shingles are painted on top only instead of dipped.
- Eavetroughs are 4" O.G. instead of 10' valley trough.
- There is no ridge-board to main building.
- Cellar walls are leaking badly & plaster in school-room is badly cracked.

These are some of the shortcomings, but there are many more.
The front steps are a disgrace to the building. The whole of the work that is covered is "shoddy."

The first inspector worked hand-in-hand with the contractor, knew it needed a man used to inspecting buildings, some above who can be relied on for honesty to go over the work from cellar to ridge.

The Dept. would save both money & trouble in the future, by getting the work inspected now, before settling with contractors. I hate to get mixed up in this kind of thing, but I feel that I would be neglecting my duty, both to the Dept. & to the Indians, if I did not inform you about these conditions.

I remain, Dear Sir,

Yours very respectfully,

E. Weeks.

Dear Mr. Scott,

The contractor has left a lot of work unfinished and what he has done is very unsatisfactory not according to contract.

A STATEMENT OF FACTS!

1. Britain is financing this war, is short of labor and therefore charges us more for what we buy from her. Remember we buy a large percentage of our Supplies in Britain. Added to this increased cost we must pay to the Dominion Government a 5 per cent. War Tax on what we import from Britain, and 7½ per cent. on Supplies from other countries.

2. Supplies that were formerly purchased in Austria or Germany, where labor is cheap, must now be bought elsewhere, where a fair wage is paid, hence a large increase in our cost.

3. It is impossible to hire skilled labor. Britain took away many of our best men to work in her Munition Factories. Nearly 300,000 of our men are under arms, and the number is to be increased to 500,000. A shortage of labor means increased cost of production.

4. The increased prices WE MUST PAY, make it imperative that our customers pay us an advance on our Thirtieth Annual Catalogue listed prices. We averaged the increased costs and find that we are compelled to add 10 per cent. to selling prices given in our last Catalogue.

5. To protect the Crown—the School and the Home—You must keep business moving. Canadian Business has to stand Canada's end of the War.

This is the situation as clearly as we can express it, and we ask your co-operation under the circumstances.

Buy NOW!
Prices are more likely to go Up than Down!
May 26, 1917.

Mr. J. Russell McGregor,
Gore Bay, Ont.

The Acting Deputy Minister,

I beg to point out that an Order in Council of the 1st September 1916 authorized an expenditure of $3852.00 from the Capital funds of the Shegwaning Band to defray expenses of erecting a school house on the Shegwaning Reserve. After the contract was let extra to the amount of $500.00 were authorized, and when the work was completed the total amount expended was $4152.00. As the Order in Council covered only the original amount ($3852.00) an other Order in council is required to cover the $500.00 additional taken from the Capital Funds. The amount at credit of this Band is $61,032.00.

Accountant.

19th September, 1916.
Ottawa, September 19, 1916.

His Excellency
The Governor General in Council.

With reference to Order in Council of 1st September, 1916, approving of an expenditure of $3652.00 on the construction of a combined school house and teacher's residence on the Sheeshowaning Indian reserve, the same to be charged to the capital at the credit of the Sheeshowaning band, the undersigned begs to report that the work could not be completed for the amount of the tender, and extras to the extent of $500.00 worth had to be purchased.

As the purchase of the extras referred to was necessary, the undersigned would recommend that under Section 89 of the Indian Act authority be given for charging the said cost of $500.00 to the capital at the credit of the Sheeshowaning band, which amounts to $61,032.00.

Superintendent General
of Indian Affairs.
The recommendation to Council herewith is for an expenditure of $562.00 for extras over and above the amount of $3652.00 which was authorized by C.C. of 1st September, 1916, to be spent on the erection of a permanent school-house and teacher's residence on the Wechaga-wan- ing reserve on Manitoulin Island. $3652.00 was the amount of the lowest tender for the work.

The extras consist of such articles as a pump for the cistern, bookcases for the school room, lead piping, a flag pole, etc., etc.

Expenditures on school-houses are made from capital under Section 89 of the Indian Act without a resolution of the band.

Indian Affairs,
September 15, 1916.
INDIAN AFFAIRS:

The Board had under consideration a memorandum from the Superintendent General of Indian Affairs, reporting that the work in connection with the construction of a combined school house and teachers' residence on the Sheshagwaning Indian reserve on Manitoulin Island, could not be completed for the amount of the tender, viz: $3,652 and that it was necessary to purchase extras to the extent of $500; that the initial expenditure of $3,652 was approved by Order in Council of the 1st September, 1916, and was chargeable to the capital at the credit of the Band of the said reserve.

The Superintendent General recommends that under Section 89 of the Indian Act, authority be given for charging the further expenditure of $500 to the capital at the credit of the Sheshagwaning Band, which amounts to $61,032.

The Board concur in the above recommendation and submit the same for favourable consideration.

Sir:

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th instant, regarding the repairs required to the fence and buildings at the Shohegwaning, O. R., Indian Day School.

In reply I be, to say that you may arrange to have the wire fence around the grounds repaired and put in good condition. I have to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 28th ultimo, with reference to a tender which you received for the painting of the Sheshawining Anglican Indian Day School, both inside and outside.

In reply I beg to say it is considered that this work could be done considerably cheaper if you purchased the paint, oils, brushes, etc., required, and had the work done by Indian labour under your supervision. If you can obtain the services of one or more competent Indians to do the work, you may purchase the quantity of paint, oils, etc., required. Competitive prices should be obtained, and the material should be purchased from the firm quoting you the lowest price. Time sheets, in duplicate, should be kept for the labour employed. The local rate of wages for the locality will apply. The building should receive a coat of good paint on both the outside and inside, and the work should be completed to your satisfaction. This work should be carried out during the present summer vacation, and when completed, you should forward properly certified vouchers, in duplicate, covering the cost of the material, and time sheets, in duplicate, properly certified, for the labour employed.

The Department will leave this matter in your hands to make the best arrangements you can for the employment of Indian labour, and in having the painting done at the lowest possible cost.

Your obedient servant,

J. D. McLean,
Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

All current expenses for this school were met from Vote, until the fiscal year 1917-18. | 1920-21 | 275.95   |
| 1921-22 | 367.55   |
| 1922-23 | 97.91    |

I wish to recommend that all current expenses of the Sheeshgwaning C. of E. Indian Day School be paid from Appropriation.

To His Excellency the Governor General of Canada

In Council,

The petition of the Indians and half breeds of the Reservation of Michipicoton, Lake Superior, humbly sheweth:

That your Petitioners, fully convinced of the benefit of an Indian and English education for their children, have built a school-house near the Post of the Hudson's Bay Company, Michipicoton, where they have a Reservation.

That we the Catholic portion of our Band, have built the said school-house near the Catholic Church with our portion of the Surplus Distribution Fund allotted to us by the Government of Ontario.

That thirty-two Catholic families with forty children of school-age live within a quarter of a mile of said school-house.

That although said school-house has been built with the money of the Catholic Indians only, yet the Catholic Indians have no objection that our Protestant friends send their children to said School, provided the teacher be a member of the Roman Catholic faith and approved by our Bishop or the Priest attending to our spiritual wants.

That your Petitioners have begged of their Bishop, the Right Rev. J. J. Samot, respectfully to request your Excellency to allow them the annual grant of two hundred dollars to make up the salary of the Teacher.

And your Petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

MEMORANDUM

Department of Indian Affairs,

To Deputy Minister,

Ottawa, Oct. 5th, 1889

I beg to state that in 1880, through the exertions of the late Bishop James, the department decided to establish an Indian School at Michipicoten and appropriated the sum of $200 per annum to pay the teacher's salary. Miss Parker was appointed to teach the school in 1882. I taught March June July 2 quarters of that year. Since that time the school has been closed and Mr. Van Abbott states in his last tabular statement that there are 76 children of school age on the Res of the Michipicoten & Big Bluffs Band.

I think that an endeavor should be made to have the school re-opened. Mr. Abbott states in his annual report that there are 30 children of school age on this Res. I would recommend that he be asked to explain this difference between his tabular statement and what he states in his report.

Fort Williams, Oct. 25th October 1877

J. A. Smart, Esq.,
Dept. Superintendent, Gen'l of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa.

Sir,

Allow me to bring to your notice, that the Indians living on Michipicoten Reserve stand in sore need of a teacher for their children, whom there are at present, 21 of school age. They are quite anxious to see their school at last opened once more, as for the last 12 years, their boys and girls have been deprived from the benefits of education, which your Department always so liberally grants to other Bands, and that too without any fault of theirs. They are an intelligent lot of people capable of appreciating the advantages of learning.

A couple of years ago, their school-house, a neat log building one story high, plastered inside & clapboarded outside, was moved up to the head of its former place down the river, through the kindness of your Department, and the people felt confident that school would at last be opened again. I made application to Ottawa for the salary of a teacher, a little over a year ago, the then Deputy Superintendent replied that the Department would make an effort to obtain a grant for that purpose at the next session of Parliament. I suppose the move was not voted, as no salary was granted.

I herewith renew my application, hoping to be more successful this time.
I would like to have the school in working order by July next.

Yours, Sir,

Your obedient servant,

(Red) Jos. Specht, M.F.
